==Hiberno-Norman texts== The annals of Ireland make a distinction made between ''Gaill'' and ''Sasanaigh''. The former were split into [[Dubgaill and Finngaill|''Fionnghaill'' or ''Dubhghaill'']], depending upon how much the poet wished to flatter his patron.<ref>See [[Art Cosgrove]], 'Hiberniores Ipsis Hibernis', ''Late Medieval Ireland 1370-1541'' (Dublin, 1981) for a discussion of the differences between 'Gaill', 'Gaedhil' and 'Saxain' in late medieval Irish identity. Fionnghaill, fair-haired foreigners, were of Norwegian descent; Dubhghaill, dark-haired foreigners, were of Danish descent. The former had longer roots in Ireland and thus was, as [[Brendan Bradshaw]] demonstrated, used as a greater compliment. Normans were, of course, originally "men of the North" i.e. from [[Scandinavia]]. See CELT (http://www.ucc.ie/celt/publishd.html) for English translations of these distinctions made in all the principal late medieval Irish annals.</ref>
There are a number of texts in Hiberno-Norman French, most of them administrative (including commercial) or legal, although there are a few literary works as well.<ref>[http://www.ucc.ie/celt/frlist.html list of Hiberno-Norman French texts at CELT]</ref><ref>[http://www.ucc.ie/celt/hibfrbib.html Bibliography of Hiberno-Norman French at CELT]</ref> There is a large amount of parliamentary legislation, including the famous [[Statute of Kilkenny]] and municipal documents.
The major literary text is ''[[The Song of Dermot and the Earl]]'', a [[chanson de geste]] of 3,458 lines of verse concerning [[Dermot McMurrough]] and [[Richard de Clare, 2nd Earl of Pembroke]] (known as "Strongbow").<ref>[http://www.ucc.ie/celt/published/F250001-001/index.html Online text of Song of Dermot and the Earl at CELT]</ref> Other texts include the ''Walling of New Ross'' composed about 1275, and early 14th century poems about the customs of [[Waterford]].

[[File:Brooklyn Museum 70.72.6 Osanyin Staff Topped by Abstract Figure of a Bird.jpg|thumbnail|Osanyin Staff Topped by Abstract Figure of a Bird, Brooklyn Museum]] [[File:COLLECTIE TROPENMUSEUM Smeedijzeren staf met vogelfiguren gebruikt bij het heiligdom van Ossanyin god van de levenskracht TMnr 3841-1.jpg|thumbnail|Osanyin staff]]
[[Yoruba people|Yoruba]] herbalists and [[Yoruba religion|priests]] enlist the aid of [[Osanyin]], the spirit of herbal medicines,<ref name="Vogel 1981">{{cite book|title=[http://libmma.contentdm.oclc.org/cdm/compoundobject/collection/p15324coll10/id/71017/rec/1 For spirits and kings : African art from the Paul and Ruth Tishman collection] : [Exhibition held at the Metropolitan museum of art, New York, 1981]|year=1981|publisher=Metropolitan Museum of Art|location=New York|isbn=0870992686|author=Thompson, additional research by Kate Ezra ; photographs by Jerry L.|editor=Susan Vogel}}</ref> or Opa Erinle, in their work against mental and physical illness caused by malevolent forces and individuals. The Yoruba believe the power of Osanyin is vested in a wrought iron staff, called an '''Osanyin staff''', that is placed on altars to this [[Orisha]].
The staff is composed of a circle of small birds and a shaft in the middle that elevates a large bird above smaller ones. [[Babatunde Lawal]] suggests that the reason for this division could be to suggest the relaying of metaphysical powers from the celestial to the terrestrial realm. Lawal evokes the Yoruba reference to Osanyin as "The one who sees everything, like [[Olodumare]]," allowing him a vantage point from which he can protect all of humanity below.<ref name=Lawal>{{cite book|last=Lawal|first=Babatunde|title=Embodying the sacred in Yoruba art : featuring the Bernard and Patricia Wagner Collection|year=2007|publisher=High Museum of Art|location=Atlanta, Ga.|isbn=1932543201}}</ref>
The birds, emissaries of [[Ogun]], refer to the herbalist's understanding of and power over these malevolent people. There are typically sixteen birds, invoking the most sacred number of divination, surrounding and confronting the central bird, which represents the smallpox god. <ref name=Yale>{{cite web|title=Herbalist's Staff (Opa Osanyin or Opa Erinle)|url=http://ecatalogue.art.yale.edu/detail.htm?objectId=61022|work=Yale University Art Gallery eCatalogue|publisher=Yale University|accessdate=26 March 2013}}</ref>
The birds on Osanyin staffs suggest an iconographic link with the birds on [[Oba's crown|Obas' crowns]].<ref name=Drewal>{{cite book|last=Drewal|first=Henry John|title=Yoruba : nine centuries of African art and thought|year=1989|publisher=Center for African Art in Association with H.N. Abrams|location=New York|isbn=0810917947|edition=2nd print.|author2=Wardwell, John Pemberton, 3rd with Rowland Abiodun |author3= edited by Allen}}</ref>

The club was founded in 1900 and was moved to its current location in 1921.{{cite news | title = Articles of Incorporation of the Phoenix Country Club | date = November 27, 1900 | work = Arizona Republic}}{{cite news | title = Phoenix Country Club 18-Hole Grass Golf Course Will Open Today -- One of Finest in West | date = October 1, 1921 | work = Arizona Republic}} Golf Connoisseur Magazine rated Phoenix Country Club among top 100 Most Prestigious Private Clubs in America in 2006. The Club was chosen for the “ultimate mix of course, history, membership, tradition and class.” In 2009 and again in 2014, Phoenix Country Club was selected by its peers as a Platinum Club of America. The original golf course designed by Harry Collis was redesigned by [[Tom Lehman]] and [[John Fought]] in 2002.{{cite web|url=http://www.phoenixcountryclub.com/club/scripts/public/public.asp?GRP=14415&NS=PUBLIC|title=Phoenix Country Club About The Club Home|website=www.phoenixcountryclub.com}} ==History== [[File:Phoenix Country Club site plan.png|thumb|Original 1920 site plan for Phoenix Country Club created by Lloyd Wright]] [[File:Phoenix Country Club veranda.png|thumb|The veranda on the front of the original clubhouse facing southwest, 1921.]] [[File:Phoenix Country Club formalwear advertisement.png|thumb|A local formalwear advertisement for the occasion of the 1921 inaugural ball]] Phoenix Country Club was officially incorporated on October 25, 1900 by a 12-member board including [[Webster Street]], Chief Justice of the Arizona Territorial Supreme Court; and [[Dwight B. Heard]], president of the Arizona Cotton Association. On October 29, 1919, the club voted to purchase a 160-acre tract of land at 7th Street and Thomas Road for the construction of a new club with and 18-hole golf course, tennis grounds, and a club house. This new property was to become the current location for the club.Arizona Republic, October 30, 1919 The land was purchased for $56,000. Golf course designer Harry Collis, of the [[Flossmoor Country Club]] in Chicago was hired to design the layout for the new course in 1920. Los Angeles-based Landscape Architect [[Lloyd Wright]] designed the landscape gardening plans for the course.Von Breton, Harriette. (1974) ''Lloyd Wright, architect: 20th century architecture in an organic expostion, volume 6,'' p24 A former employee of the landscape architectural firm of [[Olmsted Brothers]], Wright was the son of architect [[Frank Lloyd Wright]] and was noted for his landscape design of the [[Panama-California Exposition]] in San Diego, and later became a production designer for [[Paramount Studios]].Arizona Republic, January 14, 1920 To fund the construction of the new $200,000 club facilities, 52 homesites were incorporated into the plans for the new location and are known as "Country Club Estates."Arizona Republic, May 19, 1920 The new club opened on October 27, 1921. A [[white tie]] ball celebrating the opening of the new club was held on October 28 and was restricted to membership. The following day, the golf course was inaugurated with a men's golf tournament alongside a bridge tournament for female members. The original clubhouse was of brick, painted white, with red tile roofing. It was of the Spanish Colonial style of architecture, the main portion of the structure facing a southwesterly direction. From this main portion were two wings, on at each end extending in northeasterly and southeasterly directions, respectively.Arizona Republic, October 27, 1921 The building featured a main reception hall, ballroom, and banquet hall; men's and women's locker facilities and showers; a men's grill room; a dining room; large ornamented tile fireplaces; french foors; and verandas where afternoon tea was commonly served. Also featured were a swimming pool and four tennis courts. The entire structure was designed by Phoenix architectural firm [[Lescher & Kibbey]]. On September 12, 1922, the body of Phoenix Country Club secretary Guy N. Dernier was found, strangled to death and cast into the [[Arizona Canal]]. No water was found in his lungs during the autopsy meaning that he had been strangled before he was disposed of in the canal. In his [[Dodge]] automobile, parked along the canal bank, were his eyeglasses, watch, purse and articles of clothing. Found among his personal effects was a diary implicating twenty two society women in both Phoenix and Los Angeles with whom he had carried out affairs. Many of the women had compensated him for their liaisons, one paying him $600. Of the twenty two women all were married but one, a widow. Dernier had been an employee of [[Montgomery Ward]] in Chicago and came to Phoenix in 1917 for treatment for [[tuberculosis]]. He was a members of the [[Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks]].Arizona Republic, September 16, 1922 It was the opinion of the police that one of the twenty one husbands of the women with whom Dernier had had an affair was the murderer.Chicago Tribune, October 6, 1922 Following the opening of their new club, Phoenix Country Club became the seat of leadership for the Border States Tennis Association, a member of the [[United States Tennis Association|United States Lawn Tennis Association]] with members in [[Arizona]], [[New Mexico]], [[Sonora]], and [[Texas]]. The president and treasurer of the association were members [[Dwight B. Heard]] and Mrs. [[Ernest W. Lewis]], respectively.Wright & Ditson (1921) ''Wright & Ditson's Officially Adopted Lawn Tennis Guide'' p190 The Phoenix Open was first hosted at Phoenix Country Club in 1932 but was discontinued after the 1935 tournament. The rebirth of the Phoenix Open came in 1939 when member Bob Goldwater, Sr. convinced fellow Thunderbirds to help run the event. The Thunderbirds, a prominent civic organization in Phoenix, were not as enthusiastic about running the event as he was, leaving Goldwater, Sr. to do most of the work in getting a golf open started.{{cite web|url=https://wmphoenixopen.com/spectator-info/tournament-history/|title=TOURNAMENT HISTORY – Waste Management Phoenix Open|website=wmphoenixopen.com}} Beginning in 1955, the Arizona Country Club alternated as event host with Phoenix Country Club; this arrangement lasted until Phoenix Country Club took The Arizona Country Club's turn in 1975 and became the event's permanent home again.{{cite web|url=http://www.azcountryclub.com/Golf-(1).aspx|title=Arizona Country Club - Phoenix, AZ - Golf|website=www.azcountryclub.com}} The tournament was moved in 1987 to its current home, the Stadium Course at [[TPC of Scottsdale]], northeast of downtown Phoenix. During its time as host of the Phoenix Open, the club hosted such notable golfers as [[Ben Hogan]], [[Byron Nelson]], [[Jack Nicklaus]], [[Arnold Palmer]], [[Gene Littler]], [[Johnny Miller]], [[Miller Barber]], [[Ben Crenshaw]], [[Hal Sutton]], and many others.{{cite web|url=http://www.phoenixcountryclub.com/club/scripts/library/view_document.asp?GRP=..&NS=PUBLIC&APP=80&DN=HISTORY|title=Phoenix Country Club View Library Document: History|website=www.phoenixcountryclub.com}} The club also hosted the [[Western Open]] in 1941 and 1942.{{cite web|url=http://golfblogger.com/tag/phoenix-open/|title=Phoenix Open Archives - GolfBlogger Golf Blog|website=GolfBlogger Golf Blog}} In 1961, a new contemporary clubhouse designed by the architectural firm [[Edward L. Varney|Edward L. Varney & Associates]] was constructed adjacent to the old clubhouse at a cost of $1,000,000. The new clubhouse is 68,000 square feet in size and features a second floor with 35 guest rooms, larger kitchen and dining facilities and larger locker room facilities. A new swimming pool and seven additional tennis courts were also constructed. The original clubhouse was demolished soon after the completion of the new clubhouse and was replaced with a new terrace. The 1961 clubhouse continues to serve as the clubhouse for Phoenix Country Club.Arizona Republic, October 22, 1959 In 2002, the 80-year-old Collis course was redesigned by Tom Lehman and John Faught. In 2017, Phoenix Country Club became the host of the [[Charles Schwab Cup Championship]], the season finale of the [[PGA Tour Champions]]. ==Notable Members== Notable current and former members Include: *[[Emil Ganz]] (1838-1922), Businessman and three-time mayor of Phoenix, ArizonaDavis, Michael. [[Population health]], a field which focuses on the improvement of the health outcomes for a group of individuals, has been described as consisting of three components: "health outcomes, patterns of health determinants, and policies and interventions".<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kindig|first=David|last2=Stoddart|first2=Greg|date=2016-10-15|title=What Is Population Health?|pmc=1447747|journal=American Journal of Public Health|volume=93|issue=3|pages=380–383|issn=0090-0036|pmid=12604476|doi=10.2105/ajph.93.3.380}}</ref> Policies and Interventions define the methods in which [[Health outcomes research|health outcomes]] and patterns of [[health determinant]]s are implemented. Policies which are helpful "improve the conditions under which people live".<ref name=Milio/> Interventions encourage healthy behaviors for individuals or populations through "program elements or strategies designed to produce behavior changes or improve health status".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://health.mo.gov/data/interventionmica/index_4.html|title=What is an intervention?|website=health.mo.gov|access-date=2016-10-15}}</ref>
Policies and interventions are needed due to the inequalities amongst populations and the inconsistent way care is administered. Policies can include "necessary community and personal social and health services" <ref name=Milio/> as well as taxes on alcohol and soft drinks and implement smoking cessation policies. Interventions can include therapeutic or preventative health care and may also include actions taken by the individual or by someone on behalf of the individual. The application of population health is determined by the policies and interventions which can be implemented within an organization, city, state or country.
== Common methodology == Countries, states, provinces and providers across the globe are shifting towards better systems to respond to inconsistent health outcomes, mitigate decreasing margins and replace outdated methods such as [[fee-for-service]] health delivery. Payment model reforms, including the [[Accountable Care Organization]] (ACO), provide roadmaps for healthcare reform and drive many of its constituents towards more effective and innovative means for improving health outcomes. Population health management is a common approach for resolving these challenges but it involves new methods, tools, systems and implementations to correct inefficiencies and improve health outcomes.
Population health tools and computer systems include data exchange, large datasets, and advanced software which are used to supply data scientists and research teams with appropriate information which can then be used by policy makers and change agents. This method helps to set policies around population health as well as intervention strategies which are then used to respond to the needs of a population.
== Policies and Policymakers == Policy for population health "sets priorities" <ref name=Milio>{{Cite journal|last=Milio|first=N|date=2016-10-10|title=Glossary: healthy public policy*|pmc=1731988|journal=Journal of Epidemiology and Community Health|volume=55|issue=9|pages=622–623|doi=10.1136/jech.55.9.622|issn=0143-005X|pmid=11511639}}</ref> and are a "guide to action to change what would otherwise occur".<ref name=Milio/> Policies are based on "social sciences of sociology, economics, demography, public health, anthropology, and epidemiology" <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kindig|first=David A|date=2016-10-13|title=Understanding Population Health Terminology|pmc=2690307|journal=The Milbank Quarterly|volume=85|issue=1|pages=139–161|doi=10.1111/j.1468-0009.2007.00479.x|issn=0887-378X|pmid=17319809}}</ref> and determine how outcomes can be accomplished are implemented at various levels. Such guides determine laws, policies, and ordinances and are defined by policymakers. Examples of policies include "smoking bans, excise taxes on cigarettes and alcohol, seat belt laws, water fluoridation, and restaurant menu labeling".<ref>http://www.improvingpopulationhealth.org/blog/policies-and-programs.html</ref> They may be applied to a commercial establishment such as a restaurant, business workplace or within a city or state level. Policies should be evidence based and require academic studies or research to support the approach. This will assure that the appropriate measures needed for each demographic are promoted to encourage the necessary intervention practices which can be applied to each population or to the nation as a whole.
Policymakers can be classified as both private and public and are defined as someone who is in a position of authority to implement health policies. A public policy maker could be a government official and a private policymaker could be a business owner or administrator. Policymakers are influenced by, and can also be, change agents. Change agents include "legislators in Washington, an attorney general, regulators at the FDA, an advocacy group or other organizations that clearly have influence".<ref>{{cite video | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UO696h_jwRc | title = "Building Bridges to Improve Population Health” (2015) – Public Policy Presentation #2
| people = Interdisciplinary Association for Population Health Science (IAPHS), Christina Roberto, Ph.D. | date = Nov 18, 2015
| medium = YouTube | language = English | access-date = Oct 9, 2016 | time = 2:33 }}</ref>
== Political strategy == The goal for any political strategies surrounding population health is to "improve chances of success for policy adoption and implementation".<ref name=Milio/> Such strategies include the creation of funds to support initiatives and the construction of strategies which limit conflicts of interest in the implementation of public policy.
=== Tobacco Control === A political strategy implemented to limit the sale and exposure to tobacco products and restrict the tobacco company's ability to benefit politically from charitable donations is the creation of the [[WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control|World Health Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (FCTC)]] treaty. The legally binding document is supported by numerous countries, government/nongovernment agencies and provides the necessary power to prevent negative influences on population health policies.
== Interventions == Interventions in population health "shift the distribution of health risk by addressing the underlying social, economic and environmental conditions"<ref name=Hawe>{{Cite journal|last=Hawe|first=Penelope|last2=Potvin|first2=Louise|date=2017-02-01|title=What is population health intervention research?|pmid=19263977|journal=Canadian Journal of Public Health = Revue Canadienne De Santé Publique|volume=100|issue=1|pages=Suppl I8–14|issn=0008-4263}}</ref> and are implemented through "programs or policies designed and developed in the health sector, but they are more likely to be in sectors elsewhere, such as education, housing or employment".<ref name=Hawe/> They are aimed at reducing such things as [[childhood obesity]], [[cardiovascular disease]], smoking and mental health issues throughout society. The means in which interventions are devised is through extensive research and contributions from medical scientists, researchers, and medical professionals. They are implemented by but are not limited to educators, practicing physicians, business administrators and mental health professionals.
== Approaches and Implementations ==
A typical approach includes assessing the conditions and possible improvements which can be made within the social determinants that have been identified. Each approach is handled at a state or health plan level.
One example was a workplace in China which implemented policies and interventions for their staff to fight depression. By recognizing the importance of mental health, they were able to reduce depression and improve job satisfaction across the company. The company published its research and findings to promote "enterprises taking more responsibility for the provision of mental health services to their employees".<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Sun|first=Jing|last2=Buys|first2=Nicholas|last3=Wang|first3=Xinchao|date=2013-05-14|title=Effectiveness of a Workplace-Based Intervention Program to Promote Mental Health among Employees in Privately Owned Enterprises in China|url=http://online.liebertpub.com/doi/abs/10.1089/pop.2012.0113|journal=Population Health Management|volume=16|issue=6|pages=406–414|doi=10.1089/pop.2012.0113|issn=1942-7891}}</ref>
Another example was the implementation of a smoking cessation program to the province of Ontario. Studies were performed on weekly visit rates to psychiatric emergency departments before and after the implementation. The result was a "15.5% reduction in patient visits for patients with a primary diagnosis of psychotic disorder".<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kurdyak|first=Paul|last2=Cairney|first2=John|last3=Sarnocinska-Hart|first3=Anna|last4=Callahan|first4=Russell C.|last5=Strike|first5=Carol|date=2008-11-01|title=The impact of a smoking cessation policy on visits to a psychiatric emergency department|pmid=19087472|journal=Canadian Journal of Psychiatry. Revue Canadienne De Psychiatrie|volume=53|issue=11|pages=779–782|issn=0706-7437|doi=10.1177/070674370805301110}}</ref>
== Inequalities and Variance of Implementation ==
As is the common understanding of population health, health inequalities, defined as a "generic term used to designate differences, variations, and disparities in the health achievements of individuals and groups",<ref>{{citation |pmc = 1732240 | title =A Glossary for Health Inequalities | authors= Kawachi, I, S Subramanian, and N Almeida-Filho | journal = Journal of Epidemiology and Community Health | volume = 56 | pages = 647–652 | year = 2002 | pmid=12177079 | doi=10.1136/jech.56.9.647}}</ref> must be considered to correctly implement the most effective policies and interventions. Based on a population and its socioeconomic, geographic, ethnicity and other factors, policies and interventions may vary. Policies implemented for one population may be less effective and more costly than it would be for another similar population. For example, US policies tend to be more costly than European and have less impact. Research has shown that in some instances, "Americans had worse outcomes than their international peers"<ref name=Squires>{{Cite journal|last=Squires|first=David|last2=Anderson|first2=Chloe|title=U.S. Health Care from a Global Perspective|url=http://www.commonwealthfund.org/publications/issue-briefs/2015/oct/us-health-care-from-a-global-perspective}}</ref> and also had "the lowest life expectancy at birth of the countries studied".<ref name=Squires/>

The store closed in August 2018.]] [[File:AmericanApparelPromenade.JPG|thumb|right|250px|[[American Apparel]] had not made a profit since 2009,<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/american-apparel-files-for-bankruptcy-in-the-us-a6679621.html |title= American Apparel files bankruptcy in the US |last= Hutchison |first= Clare |date= October 5, 2015 |publisher= The Independent |access-date= November 3, 2015}}</ref> and filed for [[Chapter 11 bankruptcy]] twice, once in 2015 and another in 2016.<ref name="Zoe Thomas">{{cite news |last= Thomas |first= Zoe |url= https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-34450061 |title= Will bankruptcy cost American Apparel its cool? |publisher= [[BBC News]] |date= October 5, 2015 |accessdate= October 5, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |first= Susanna |last=Kim |url= http://abcnews.go.com/Business/american-apparel-worth-billion-now-bankrupt/story?id=34263639 |title= American Apparel, Once Worth Nearly $1 Billion, Is Now Bankrupt |publisher= ABC News}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title= American Apparel Chapter 11 Voluntary Petition |url= https://www.pacermonitor.com/view/3TUJYZQ/American_Apparel_Inc__debke-15-12055__0001.0.pdf |website= PacerMonitor |publisher=PacerMonitor |accessdate= May 16, 2016}}</ref>]]
The '''retail apocalypse''' is the closing of a large number of [[economy of North America|North American]] brick-and-mortar [[retail]] stores, especially those of large chains, starting in 2010 and continuing through 2018.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.businessinsider.com/store-closures-in-2018-will-eclipse-2017-2018-1 |title=A tsunami of store closings is about to hit the US — and it's expected to eclipse the retail carnage of 2017 |last=Peterson |first=Hayley |date=January 1, 2018 |website= businessinsider.com |access-date= January 4, 2018}}</ref><ref name="atlantic" /> Over 12,000 physical stores have been closed, due to factors such as over-expansion of malls, rising rents, bankruptcies of [[leveraged buyout]]s, low quarterly profits outside holiday binge spending, delayed effects of the [[Great Recession]],<ref name="atlantic">{{Cite news|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/business/archive/2017/04/retail-meltdown-of-2017/522384/|title=What in the World Is Causing the Retail Meltdown of 2017?|first=Derek|last=Thompson|date=April 10, 2017|accessdate=April 10, 2017|publisher=''[[The Atlantic]]''}}</ref> and changes in spending habits. North American consumers have shifted their purchasing habits due to various factors, including [[experience economy |experience-spending]] versus material goods and homes, casual fashion in relaxed [[dress code]]s, as well as the rise of [[e-commerce]],<ref>[https://www.msn.com/en-us/money/companies/these-haunting-photos-of-the-retail-apocalypse-reveal-a-new-normal-in-america/ss-BByFpjX Photo slideshow of shuttered retail stores and shopping centers] ''[[Business Insider]]''</ref> mostly in the form of competition from juggernaut companies such as [[Amazon.com]] and [[Walmart]].
Major [[department store]]s such as [[J. C. Penney]], [[Macy’s]], [[Sears]], and [[Kmart]] have announced hundreds of store closures, and well-known apparel brands such as [[J. Crew]] and [[Ralph Lauren Corporation|Ralph Lauren]] are [[Profit (economics) |unprofitable]].<ref>[http://dieworkwear.com/post/163186699059/the-great-retail-apocalypse The Great Retail Apocalypse] ''Dieworkwear'' July 19, 2017.</ref> Of the 1,200 [[shopping mall]]s across the US, 50% are expected to close by 2023.<ref>Dominic Rushe. "[https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/jul/22/mall-of-america-minnesota-retail-anniversary Big, bold … and broken: is the US shopping mall in a fatal decline?]". [[theguardian.com]]. July 23, 2017.</ref> More than 12,000 stores are expected to close in 2018, and only 4,000 of them have been planned by several retailers.<ref>[http://www.businessinsider.com/store-closures-in-2018-will-eclipse-2017-2018-1 A tsunami of store closings is about to hit the US — and it's expected to eclipse the retail carnage of 2017] Hayley Peterson, [[Business Insider]], January 1, 2018 </ref> Several retailers such as [[Toys "R" Us]] and [[The Bon-Ton]] have liquidated and closed all their stores.
Recent research from IHL Group shows a net increase of more than 2,000 store openings by the end of 2018. IHL also found that for every retailer closing stores, two are adding stores, and two-thirds of the store closings are tied to just 16 stores.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.investors.com/gdpr-agreement/?back_url=https://www.investors.com/stock-lists/ibd-big-cap-20/large-caps-retail-sector-stocks/|title=Investor's Business Daily {{!}} GDPR Agreement|website=www.investors.com|access-date=2018-11-02}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.investors.com/gdpr-agreement/?back_url=https://www.investors.com/stock-lists/ibd-big-cap-20/large-caps-retail-sector-stocks/|title=Investor's Business Daily {{!}} GDPR Agreement|website=www.investors.com|access-date=2018-11-02}}</ref>
The retail apocalypse phenomenon is related to the [[middle-class squeeze]], in which consumers experience a decrease in [[income]] while costs increase for education, healthcare, and housing. [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] stated that the cause of the retail apocalypse "isn’t as simple as [[Amazon.com]] Inc. taking market share or twenty-somethings spending more on experiences than things. The root cause is that many of these long-standing chains are overloaded with debt—often from [[leveraged buyout]]s led by [[private equity]] firms."<ref>[https://www.bloomberg.com/graphics/2017-retail-debt/ America’s ‘Retail Apocalypse’ Is Really Just Beginning] Matt Townsend, Jenny Surane, Emma Orr and Christopher Cannon, [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]], November 8, 2017</ref> [[Forbes]] has said the media coverage is exaggerated, and the sector is simply evolving.<ref>[https://www.forbes.com/sites/gregmaloney/2017/10/23/retail-apocalypse-yawn/#66e651f0df2e Retail Apocalypse? The Sky Isn't Falling – The Sector Is Just Evolving] Greg Maloney, Forbes, 2017/10/23</ref> The most productive retailers in the [[United States]] during the retail apocalypse are Walmart and [[Target Corporation|Target]], some regional department store chains (e.g. [[Belk]], [[Boscov's]], [[Boyd's]], [[Dillard's]], and [[Von Maur]]), the low-cost "[[fast-fashion]]" brands (e.g. [[Zara (retailer)|Zara]], [[Uniqlo]], [[Cotton On]], [[Forever 21]], and [[H&M]]), off-price department stores ([[Ross Stores]] and DD's Discounts, [[Marshalls]] and [[Burlington (department store)|Burlington]]) and [[dollar stores]] (e.g. [[Dollar General]] and [[Family Dollar]]).<ref>[https://qz.com/1120552/the-retail-apocalypse-isnt-just-amazon-its-that-the-middle-class-is-disappearing/ The US middle class is disappearing, which makes dollar stores very happy] Helen Edwards & Dave Edwards, [[Qz.com]] 8 December 2017</ref> At least one [[private equity firm]], [[Sycamore Partners]], has made money buying assets from brick-and-mortar chains during the retail apocalypse.<ref name="Made a Fortune"> {{cite news | last= Gottfried | first= Miriam | url= https://www.wsj.com/articles/how-one-investor-made-a-fortune-picking-over-the-retail-apocalypse-1521643491 | title= How One Investor Made a Fortune Picking Over the Retail Apocalypse | publisher= ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' | date= March 21, 2018 | accessdate= }} </ref> [[Pop-up retail]], including seasonal retailers such as [[Spirit Halloween]], have become a common factor during the retail apocalypse operating temporarily in vacant spots after companies go out of business, or store closings, as a result of it.
Accompanying the store closings were, in many cases, significant declines in the stock prices of retail companies.<ref>[https://www.forbes.com/sites/ericervin/2017/05/30/finding-the-best-retail-stocks-amid-broad-declines Forbes.com]</ref>
==History== Since at least 2010, various economic factors have resulted in the closing of a large number of North American retailers, particularly in the [[department store]] industry. For instance, [[Sears Holdings]], which had 4,061 Kmart and Sears stores in the United States and Canada at the company's peak on October 29, 2011 (Q3 2011), including [[Orchard Supply Hardware]] locations that were spun off in 2012, those now spun off to [[Sears Hometown and Outlet Stores]] on October 11, 2012 and a de-consolidation of [[Sears Canada]] on October 16, 2014, was down to 866 in the United States as of August 13, 2018, with more closures scheduled.<ref name="economiccollapse">{{Cite news|url=http://theeconomiccollapseblog.com/archives/its-a-retail-apocalypse-sears-macys-and-the-limited-are-all-closing-stores|title=It’s A Retail Apocalypse: Sears, Macy’s And The Limited Are All Closing Store|first=Michael|last=Snyder|date=January 8, 2017|accessdate=April 10, 2017|publisher=The Economic Collapse}}</ref> Kmart operated 2,171 stores at its peak in 2000,<ref name="kmartannual1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/56824/000095012400002311/0000950124-00-002311.txt|title=KMART CORP Annual Report – Fiscal Year Ending January 29th, 2000.|last=|first=|date=|website=|dead-url=|access-date=April 10, 2017}}</ref> a number that has since dwindled to 360 with further closures planned.<ref name="kmartwarren">{{Cite web|url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1310067/000131006717000005/shld201610k.htm|title=SEARS HOLDINGS CORPORATION Annual Report – Fiscal Year Ending January 28th, 2017|last=|first=|date=March 21, 2017|website=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.kmart.com/stores/ohio/warren/4939.html|title=Kmart – Warren, OH 44484|last=|first=|date=March 21, 2017|website=Used phone number to confirm: 330-544-2098|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
The term "retail apocalypse" began gaining widespread usage in 2017 following multiple announcements from many major retailers of plans to either discontinue or greatly scale back a retail presence, including companies such as [[H.H. Gregg]], [[Family Christian Stores]] and [[The Limited]] all going out of business entirely.<ref name="whioohioimpact">{{Cite news|url=http://www.whio.com/business/retail-apocalypse-500-stores-more-close-this-year/RzTeZhnIk13YIlF0skFV3H|title=RETAIL APOCALYPSE: 3,500 stores or more to close this year|first=Kara|last=Driscoll|date=March 27, 2017|accessdate=April 8, 2017|publisher=[[WHIO-TV]]}}</ref> ''[[The Atlantic]]'' describes the phenomenon as "The Great Retail Apocalypse of 2017," reporting nine retail bankruptcies and several apparel companies having their stock hit new lows, including that of [[Lululemon]], [[Urban Outfitters]], [[American Eagle Outfitters|American Eagle]].<ref name="atlantic" /> [[Credit Suisse]], a major global financial services company, predicted that 25% of U.S. malls remaining in 2017 could close by 2022.<ref name="gymboree">{{Cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/2017/06/12/childrens-apparel-chain-gymboree-files-chapter-11-bankruptcy/102772792/|title=Gymboree files bankruptcy, closing up to 450 stores|first=Nathan|last=Bomey|date=June 12, 2017|accessdate=June 12, 2017|publisher=[[USA Today]]}}</ref>
The retail apocalypse has had a [[domino effect]] on suppliers; [[Hasbro]], for example, cited the loss of the Toys R Us chain as a major cause for lost revenue and layoffs the company imposed in October 2018.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.wivb.com/news/national/hasbro-points-to-toys-r-us-demise-in-announcing-layoffs/1542038375|title=Hasbro points to Toys R Us' demise in announcing layoffs|publisher=CBS News|date=October 22, 2018|accessdate=October 22, 2018}}</ref>
In the second half of 2017 and throughout 2018, the media and analyst community began recognizing retail as an industry in transition, rather than demise. [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] said in May 2018 that ‘the death of retail has been greatly exaggerated’ and Telsey Advisory Group stated that ‘retail is not dead’ in August 2018 following news that the SPDR S&P Retail ETF had risen 13% year to date to a record high, more than double the return of the S&P 500 Index.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/07/31/digital-retailers-and-foreign-brands-fill-empty-us-malls.html|title=Is the retail collapse over? Shopping mall owners think so.|last=Thomas|first=Lauren|date=2018-07-31|work=CNBC|access-date=2018-11-05}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/view/articles/2018-05-01/e-commerce-costs-rise-just-as-commercial-real-estate-costs-fall|title=The Return of the Brick-and-Mortar Store|website=www.bloomberg.com|access-date=2018-11-05}}</ref>
In June 2018, SeekingAlpha wrote that 90 percent of purchases are still made in stores, and except for Amazon, the top ten retailers are brick-and mortar operators: in order, they are Walmart, Kroger, Costco, Home Depot, CVS, Walgreens, Amazon.com, Target, Lowe’s and Albertsons.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://seekingalpha.com/article/4184162-retail-apocalypse-wake-experience-renaissance?page=3|title=What Retail Apocalypse? Wake Up And Experience The 'Renaissance'|last=Thomas|first=Brad|date=2018-06-27|work=Seeking Alpha|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en-US}}</ref> Forbes wrote in July 2018 that changing consumer behavior has forced the traditional brick-and-mortar retailers and shopping-center developers to reinvent and answer the new needs of consumers.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/andriacheng/2018/07/08/brick-and-mortar-retail-is-far-from-dead-just-look-at-whos-moving-in-to-replace-toys-r-us/#3880e0562d7b|title=Brick-And-Mortar Retail Isn't Dead: Just Look At Who's Moving Into Empty Toys 'R' Us Stores|last=Cheng|first=Andria|work=Forbes|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en}}</ref>
Numerous pureplay online retailers including Warby Parker, Untuckit, Casper, Away, Wayfair and TheRealReal have announced plans to open their first physical stores and expand their existing footprints in 2018 and beyond.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/07/31/digital-retailers-and-foreign-brands-fill-empty-us-malls.html|title=Is the retail collapse over? Shopping mall owners think so.|last=Thomas|first=Lauren|date=2018-07-31|work=CNBC|access-date=2018-11-07}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/casper-a-web-pioneer-to-open-200-stores-1533729600|title=Casper, a Web Pioneer, to Open 200 Stores|last=Safdar|first=Khadeeja|work=WSJ|access-date=2018-11-07|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.fastcompany.com/40575801/as-luggage-startups-drop-like-flies-away-beefs-up-with-249-jobs|title=As luggage startups drop like flies, Away beefs up with 249 jobs|date=2018-05-21|work=Fast Company|access-date=2018-11-07|language=en-US}}</ref>
JLL reports that digitally native brands will open 850 stores in the next five years. These retailers are finding that opening a physical store has a halo effect on web traffic: A study from the International Council of Shopping Centers shows that a new store increases traffic to that retailer’s website by an average of 37 percent and drives up share of web traffic within that market by 27 percent.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.retaildive.com/news/e-commerce-pure-plays-set-to-open-850-stores-in-five-years/539320/|title=Digitally native brands set to open 850 stores in 5 years|work=Retail Dive|access-date=2018-11-09|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://reports.icsc.org/thehaloeffect|title=The Halo Effect: How Bricks Impact Clicks|website=reports.icsc.org|language=en|access-date=2018-11-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-10-22/warby-parker-and-casper-are-coming-to-a-strip-mall-near-you|title=Warby Parker and Casper Are Coming to a Strip Mall Near You|last=|first=|date=|website=Bloomberg|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
The National Retail Federation forecasted that 2018 retail sales would climb at least 4.5 percent over 2017, pointing to higher wages, gains in disposable income, a strong job market and record-high household net worth for very robust growth in the nation's consumer-driven economy.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/08/13/retail-sales-in-2018-could-climb-higher-than-previously-forecast-nrf.html|title=2018 retail sales could climb higher than forecast, the National Retail Federation says|last=Thomas|first=Lauren|date=2018-08-13|work=CNBC|access-date=2018-11-12}}</ref>
==Affected retailers== {{main|List of retailers affected by the retail apocalypse}} [[Sears Holdings]] filed for bankruptcy protection in October 2018 and plans to close about 142 of its 700 stores by the end of 2018. [[Toys "R" Us]] filed for bankruptcy,<ref>[https://finance.yahoo.com/news/toys-r-us-just-beginning-retail-defaults-2018-182915327.html Toys "R" Us Just The Beginning of Retail Defaults in 2018] Krystal Hu, [[Yahoo! Finance]], March 15, 2018</ref> and closed all its US stores in June 2018.<ref>Brad Tuttle, [http://time.com/money/4931640/toys-r-us-sales-bankruptcy-debt/ Up Next in the Retail Apocalypse: Toys R Us?] [[Time.com]] September 7, 2017</ref><ref>[https://www.cnbc.com/2018/06/29/toys-r-us-closing-sales-stores-retail-toys.html Toys R Us closing its stores] Darren Geeter, [[CNBC]], 29 June 2018</ref>
==Unaffected retailers== {{coatrack|section|date=October 2018}} The retailers below are ones that are defying the retail apocalypse by opening stores, remodeling stores, and/or being able to surivive changing trends. [[File:Ulta Beauty Ann Arbor.JPG|thumb|right|[[Ulta Beauty]] is opening 100 stores in 2018]] [[File:Build-A-BearWorkshopVaughanMills.JPG|thumb|As of 2018, [[Build-A-Bear Workshop]] had expanded its physical footprint by 12% and had been profitable for four straight years<ref name="KRISTEN BAHLER" />]]
*[[Aldi]] is planning to open 180 new stores by the end of 2018 and grow to 2,500 stores by 2022.<ref name="openingUGT"> {{cite news | last= Thomas | first= Lauren | url= https://www.cnbc.com/2018/03/23/retailers-ulta-warby-parker-ross-stores-opening-more-locations-in-2018.html | title= Ulta, Gap, Target and more: These retailers are still opening stores in 2018 | publisher= CNBC | date= March 24, 2018 | accessdate= April 25, 2018 }}</ref> *[[At Home (store)|At Home]] opened its 150th store in 2018 and plans to open even more stores.<ref name="opening5">{{cite news | last= Driscoll | first= Kara | url= https://www.daytondailynews.com/business/retail-apocalypse-for-these-companies-retailers-opening-stores-2018/v2MSS0N51DTV7xmvqFLRqL/ | title= No retail apocalypse for these companies: 5 retailers opening stores in 2018 | publisher= daytondailynews.com | date= March 27, 2018 | accessdate= }} </ref> * [[Boscov's]], after emerging from bankruptcy in 2009,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Panaritis|first1=Maria|title=Boscov's emerges from bankruptcy|url=http://www.philly.com/philly/business/20090918_Boscov_s_emerges_from_bankruptcy.html|accessdate=23 April 2018|publisher=Philadelphia Inquirer|date=September 18, 2009}}</ref> saw record sales of $1.2 billion in 2017 and continues to open new stores.<ref name="AllabaughRight">{{cite news|last1=Allabaugh|first1=Denise|title=Boscov's doing retail right|url=http://thetimes-tribune.com/boscov-s-doing-retail-right-1.2316770|accessdate=22 April 2018|publisher=[[The Scranton Times-Tribune]]|date=25 March 2018}}</ref> * [[Build-A-Bear Workshop]] remains as the mall-based toy retailer surviving the retail apocalypse in 2018, after [[Toys 'R' Us]] announced plans to close all 735 of its U.S. stores in March 2018. <ref name="KRISTEN BAHLER"> {{cite news | last= BAHLER | first= KRISTEN | url= http://time.com/money/5216826/toys-r-us-retail-closing/ | title= As Toys R' Us Closes, Only One Major Toy Store Is Thriving in the Retail Apocalypse | publisher= [[time.com]] | date= March 27, 2018 | accessdate= }} </ref> *[[Costco Wholesale]] opened 8 new stores in the first half of fiscal year 2018 and will open 18 to 20 new stores during the second half of 2018.<ref name="opening9"> {{cite news | last= Sun | first= Leo | url= https://www.fool.com/slideshow/these-9-retailers-are-actually-opening-stores/?slide=3 | title= These 9 Retailers Are Actually Opening Stors | publisher= Montley Fool | date= April 25, 2018 | accessdate= April 25, 2018 }}</ref> *[[Dick's Sporting Goods]] will open 20 stores in 2018, though this is a slowdown compared to before. Ed Stack mentioned that they would open more locations once market rents drop.<ref name="openingUGT"/> *[[Dollar General]] will open 1,846 new stores in 2018, remodel 1,568 stores, and relocate 219 stores.<ref name="opening5"/> *[[Dollar Tree]], also operating [[Family Dollar]], opened 137 stores in fiscal year 2017. The company opened 603 new stores overall in the year of 2017.<ref name="opening17">{{cite news | last= | first= | url= https://clark.com/shopping-retail/retail-chains-opening-closing-stores-2018/ | title= These 17 retail chains are opening thousands of stores in 2018 | publisher= clark.com | date= April 6, 2018 | accessdate= April 25, 2018 }} </ref> *[[Duluth Trading Company]] plans to expand to 100 locations by 2023, mainly opening 15 stores in 2018.<ref name="openingCSA"> {{cite news | author= CSA Staff | url= https://www.chainstoreage.com/store-spaces/specialty-apparel-retailer-plots-nationwide-expansion/ | title= Specialty apparel retailer plots nationwide expansion | publisher= Chain Store Age | date= May 7, 2018 | accessdate= May 7, 2018 }}</ref> *[[Fabletics]] plans to open 50 to 100 stores in the next five years.{{fact|date=July 2018}} *[[Five Below]] will open 125 stores in 2018.<ref name="opening17"/> *[[Gap Inc.]], despite closing 200 locations by 2020, is opening 270 stores under the [[Old Navy]] and Athleta brands.<ref name="openingUGT"/> *[[Hobby Lobby]] will open 60 new locations in 2018.<ref name="opening17"/> *[[Home Depot]] routinely reports a profit, and new stores are being planned{{when|date=July 2018}} on opening. *[[Ollie's Bargain Outlet]] will open 36 to 38 new stores in 2018.<ref name="opening17"/> *[[Ross Stores]] will open 75 Ross stores and 25 DD's Discounts stores in 2018.<ref name="openingUGT"/> *[[Target Corporation|Target]] is planning to open 35 small format stores in 2018 and remodel more than 300 existing stores.<ref name="opening5"/> *[[Tillys]] is opening new stores{{when|date=July 2018}} across the US. *[[TJX Companies]], owner of [[T.J. Maxx]], [[HomeGoods]], [[Marshalls]], etc. opened 258 by fiscal year 2018 for a total of 4,070 stores as of the fiscal year.<ref name="opening17"/> *In 2018, [[Party City]] announced that they will be opening their first Toy City stores by September 2018, filling the void left by Toys "R" Us.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://fortune.com/2018/06/25/party-city-toys-holiday/|title=Party City joins the list of retailers feasting on Toys 'R' Us remains|work=Fortune|access-date=2018-07-13|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/06/25/party-city-to-open-toy-city-stores-in-wake-of-toys-r-us-demise.html|title=Party City to open Toy City stores in wake of Toys R Us' demise|first=Lauren|last=Thomas|date=25 June 2018|publisher=|accessdate=26 June 2018}}</ref> *[[Tractor Supply Company]] opened 101 new stores in 2017, with plans to open 80 stores during 2018.<ref>{{cite web |title=Tractor Supply Opens 1,700th Store, Growth Plans on Track |url=https://www.nasdaq.com/article/tractor-supply-opens-1700th-store-growth-plans-on-track-cm943518 |publisher=Nasdaq |accessdate=10 November 2018}}</ref> *[[Uniqlo]] is opening new stores.{{fact|date=July 2018}} *[[UNTUCKit]] plans to open 25 new stores in 2018, and grow to 100 stores by 2022.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.retailtouchpoints.com/features/news-briefs/untuckit-continues-physical-expansion-with-25-new-stores-in-2018|publisher=Retail Touch Points|title=UNTUCKit Continues Physical Expansion With 25 New Stores In 2018|date=May 18, 2018|accessdate=June 27, 2018}}</ref> *[[Ulta Beauty]] will open around 100 new stores and remodel 17 existing stores in fiscal year 2018.<ref name="opening5"/> *[[Walmart]] opened 89 stores in 2017 and will open more in 2018. No exact target has been disclosed as of April 2018.<ref name="opening9"/> *[[Warby Parker]], an eyeglass retailer, will open 40 stores by the end of 2018.<ref name="opening5"/> *[[Z Gallerie]] is opening new stores across the US.{{fact|date=July 2018}}
==Factors== {{Quote box | title = | quote = ...several trends—including the rise of [[e-commerce]], the over-supply of malls, and the surprising effects of a restaurant renaissance—have conspired to change the face of American shopping. | source = ''[[The Atlantic]]''<ref name="atlantic" /> | align = right | width = 10em | border = 1px | fontsize = 85% | bgcolor = #c6dbf7 | title_bg = | title_fnt = | salign = right }} The main factor cited in the closing of retail stores in the retail apocalypse is the shift in consumer habits towards online shopping.<ref>Kyle Arnold, [http://www.orlandosentinel.com/business/consumer/os-bz-retail-apocalypse-20170716-story.html Retail apocalypse? Online competition drives store closings] ''[[Orlando Sentinel]]'', July 16, 2017</ref> Holiday sales for e-commerce were reported as increasing by 11% for 2016 compared with 2015 by Adobe Digital Insights, with Slice Intelligence reporting an even more generous 20% increase. Comparatively, brick-and-mortar stores saw an overall increase of only 1.6%, with physical department stores experiencing a 4.8% decline.<ref name="practicale">{{Cite news|url=http://www.practicalecommerce.com/articles/132707-2016-Holiday-Ecommerce-Wrap-up|title=2016 Holiday Ecommerce Wrap-up|first=Marcia|last=Kaplan|date=January 12, 2017|accessdate=April 8, 2017|publisher=PracticalEcommerce}}</ref> Another factor is an over-supply of [[shopping mall|malls]],<ref>Marc Bain, [https://qz.com/1032723/theres-much-more-empty-retail-space-in-the-us-than-in-other-countries-on-a-per-capita-level/ America’s vast swaths of retail space have become a burden in the age of e-commerce] [[qz.com]] July 19, 2017</ref> as the growth rate of malls between 1970 and 2015 was over twice the growth rate of the population. In 2004, [[Malcolm Gladwell]] wrote that investment in malls was artificially accelerated when the [[United States Congress|U.S. Congress]] introduced [[accelerated depreciation]] into the tax code in 1954.<ref>{{cite magazine |last=Gladwell |first=Malcolm |date=March 15, 2004 |title=The Terrazzo Jungle |url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2004/03/15/the-terrazzo-jungle |magazine=[[The New Yorker]] |access-date=November 9, 2017 }}</ref> Despite the construction of new malls, mall visits declined by 50% between 2010-2013 with further declines reported in each successive year.<ref>Josh Sanburn, [http://time.com/4865957/death-and-life-shopping-mall/ Why the Death of Malls Is About More Than Shopping] ''[[Time (magazine)|TIME]]'', July 20, 2017</ref> A third major reported factor is the "restaurant renaissance," a shift in consumer spending habits for their disposable cash from material purchases such as clothing towards [[restaurant|dining out]] and [[travel]].<ref name="atlantic" /> Another cited factor is the "[[Middle-class squeeze|death]] of the [[American middle class]]," resulting in large-scale closures of retailers such as [[Macy's]] and [[Sears]], which traditionally relied on spending from this market segment.<ref name="middleclass">{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/amazon-and-walmart-confirm-the-death-of-the-middle-class-2017-6|title=Amazon's and Walmart's latest moves confirm the death of the middle class as we know it|first=Hayley|last=Peterson|date=June 6, 2017|accessdate=June 6, 2017|publisher=''[[Business Insider]]''}}</ref> The final factor in poor brick-and-mortar sales performance is a combination of poor retail management coupled with an overcritical eye towards quarterly dividends: a lack of accurate inventory control creates both underperforming and out-of-stock merchandise, causing a poor shopping experience for customers in order to optimize short-term balance sheets,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/paularosenblum/2014/04/15/walmarts-out-of-stock-problem-only-half-the-story/#1fb788873696|title=Walmart's Out Of Stock Problem: Only Half The Story?|last=Rosenblum|first=Paula|work=Forbes|access-date=2017-12-14|language=en}}</ref> the latter of which also influences the desire to understaff retail stores in order to keep claimed profits high.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.rsrresearch.com/research/the-walmart-out-of-stock-problem-lessons-learned|title=The Walmart Out-of-Stock Problem: Lessons Learned|website=www.rsrresearch.com|access-date=2017-12-14}}</ref> Furthermore several private-equity forms have bought many retailers and loaded them with extraordinary amounts of debt, which hinders the profitable operation of retail chains<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://newrepublic.com/article/147669/real-retail-killer|title=The Real Retail Killer|work=The New Republic|access-date=2018-11-27|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.businessinsider.com/brick-and-mortar-retail-private-equity-debt-financing-lbo-2017-8?international=true&r=US&IR=T|title=The retail apocalypse is being fueled by private equity firms adding to debt loads|work=Business Insider|access-date=2018-11-27}}</ref>.

{{Medical anthropology}} The '''Organization of Medical Anthropology''' was formed in 1967 and first met on April 27, 1968, at the 27th Annual Meeting of the [[Society for Applied Anthropology]] (SfAA), during which the Medical Anthropology Newsletter was conceived and first published in October 1968 with 53 subscribers. On November 22, 1968, the Organization held its first medical anthropology workshop at the [[American Anthropological Association]] (AAA) Annual Meeting and became the '''Group for Medical Anthropology''' ('''GMA'''). Thereafter, medical anthropology meetings have met regularly both at the SfAA and AAA meetings. At the AAA Annual Meeting in San Diego, California, in November 1970, the GMA became the '''Society for Medical Anthropology''' ('''SMA''') and adopted its Constitution, of which its first objective was “to promote study of anthropological aspects of health, illness, health care, and related topics.” In 1971, the SMA became a section of the AAA.
The SMA offers several awards including the [[Rudolf Virchow Award]].

{{Other uses|Indian South Africans}}{{Infobox ethnic group | group = Tamil South Africans | image = | caption = | population = 600,000{{Citation needed|date=October 2010}} | popplace = [[KwaZulu-Natal]] | langs = [[English language|English]], [[Tamil language|Tamil]], [[Languages of South Africa]] | rels = [[Hinduism in South Africa|Hinduism]] ,[[Christianity]] | related = }} {{Tamils}} '''Tamil South Africans''' are South Africans of [[Tamil people|Tamil]] descent. Tamil people form the majority of Indian immigrants who came from [[India]] to [[Colony of Natal|Natal, South Africa]], from 1860 onwards.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sahistory.org.za/article/indian-south-africans|title=Indian South Africans|first=|last=sahoboss|date=21 March 2011|publisher=}}</ref> After the expiry of their indentures most of these Indians moved to the cities, becoming established as a thoroughly urban population.<ref name=AD/><ref>{{cite web |url= http://scnc.ukzn.ac.za/doc/SHIP/caste.html |title= Caste and Religions of Natal Immigrants |author= K. Chetty |publisher=Gandhi-Luthuli Documentation Centre |accessdate=2007-11-19}}</ref>
==Arrival in South Africa== In 1833, the British Parliament passed the Act of Abolition, which banned slavery throughout the British Empire. The consequence of this was that many African slaves in the Colony of Natal decided to desert their former masters. The former masters, lacking sufficient labour force, persuaded the skeptical British authorities in India to implement the system of indentured labour in Natal. On November 16, 1860, 342 men, women and children arrived aboard the S.S. ''Truro'' in Port Natal (Durban).
==Apartheid== [[Apartheid]] alienated all Indians as disenfranchised ''non-whites'', and [[Hinduism in South Africa|Hinduism]] in particular was perceived by many whites as antithetical to [[Christianity]]. The imposition of apartheid system also curtailed the opportunities for improvement and included the forced removals program, causing great disruption and social hardship.<ref name=AD/>
==Integration== Over the 150 years of residence in South Africa, participation in religion and its many festivals has brought devotees a valuable sense of identity and solidarity, especially in the light of their marginalization and the discrimination experienced under the apartheid system. A recent resurgence of interest in indigenous Tamil festivals seems to reflect a variety of religious, social and political concerns.<ref name=AD>{{cite conference | first = Alleyn | last = Diesel | title = Tamil Hindus in KawZulu-Natal (South Africa): History, Identity and the Establishment of Their Place in the New South Africa |booktitle = Proceedings from the International Association for the History of Religions | publisher = International Association for the History of Religions (IAHR), | year= 2000 | location = | accessdate = }}</ref> In South Africa, the Tamil community tend to refer to their religion as "Tamil", rather than Hindu, although this blurring of the distinctions between religion and language also occurs with other Hindu ethnic groups in South Africa.<ref name="Bongmba2012">{{cite book|author=Elias Kifon Bongmba|title=The Wiley-Blackwell Companion to African Religions|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JFRRl1vv0kwC&pg=PA393|date=21 May 2012|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=978-1-4051-9690-1|pages=393–}}</ref>
==Education== South African Tamils are said to be the most educated people group in the world with an average of (3.6 pHDs per 100 People).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jagranjosh.com/current-affairs/five-indian-languages-reinstated-as-official-subjects-in-south-african-schools-1395392591-1|title=Five Indian languages reinstated as official subjects in South African schools|date=21 March 2014|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kzneducation.gov.za/Portals/0/Circuiars/General/2014/MERCURY%20(First%20Edition)%20-%20p.3%20-%2011%20Mar%202014.pdf|title=five indian languages - Kwazulu - Natal Education Ministry|publisher=}}</ref>
==Festivals== "Purataasi" is the Tamil month from mid-September to mid-October and is a period dedicated to Lord Vishnu.The entire period of Purataasi is observed with the abstention of meat, sexual pleasures and intoxicants. The main prayer in every Tamil-cultured home is held on any of the four Saturdays during the period and much effort is put into this.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ulwazi.org/index.php5?title=Purtuassi_in_Durban|title=Ulwazi - Top Product Reviews 2018|website=Ulwazi Wiki}}</ref>
The Tamil Community in South Africa also observe the Mariamman Festival in the Aadi Month which falls between mid-July and mid-August. Due to the fact that Maize Meal forms a large part in the Mariamman worship this prayer is usually referred to as "Porridge Prayers" by the locals.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ulwazi.org/index.php5?title=The_Mariamman_Festival_in_Durban,_KwaZulu_Natal|title=Ulwazi - Top Product Reviews 2018|website=Ulwazi Wiki}}</ref>
Kavadi is another famous festival among the Tamil community amongst the Tamil Community in South Africa. Such an example is the Melrose Sri Siva Subramaniar Alayam in Johannesburg that was first a steel temple dedicated to Lord Muruga and was built in 1890 and today attracts thousands of devotees during the [[Thaipusam|Thai Poosam]] festival.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ulwazi.org/index.php5?title=Kavady_Festival|title=Ulwazi - Top Product Reviews 2018|website=Ulwazi Wiki}}</ref>
