Begin decommissioning of existing telescopes. | methods = {{hlist|[[Blockade]]|[[Occupation (protest)|Occupation]]|[[Civil disobedience]]|[[Picketing (protest)|Picketing]]|[[Demonstration (people)|Demonstrations]]|[[Internet activism]]|[[Petitions]]|[[lawsuits]]}} | status = | result = | side1 = | side2 = | side3 = | leadfigures1 = | leadfigures2 = | leadfigures3 = | howmany1 = | howmany2 = | howmany3 = | casualties1 = | casualties2 = | casualties3 = | fatalities = | injuries = | arrests =31<ref>{{cite news|title=31 Arrested On Mauna Kea, Mauna Kea Hui Responds|url=http://www.bigislandvideonews.com/2015/04/02/31-arrested-on-mauna-kea-mauna-kea-hui-responds/|accessdate=20 April 2015|agency=Big Island Video News|publisher=Big Island Video News|date=April 2, 2015}}</ref> | detentions = | charged = | fined = | casualties_label = | notes = }}
The '''Thirty Meter Telescope protests''' are a series of protests and demonstrations that began on the [[Island of Hawaii]] in the United States over the choosing of [[Mauna Kea]] for the site location of the [[Thirty Meter Telescope]]. Mauna Kea is considered the most sacred mountain of Native [[Hawaiian religion]] and culture. Protests began locally within the state of Hawaii on October 7, 2014 but went global within weeks of the April 2, 2015 arrest of 31 people who had blockaded the roadway to keep construction crews off the summit.
The TMT, a ground-based, large [[segmented mirror]] [[reflecting telescope]] grew from astronomers' prioritization in 2000 of a thirty-meter telescope to be built within the decade. Mauna Kea was announced as TMT's preferred site in 2009. Opposition to the project began shortly after the announcement of Mauna Kea as the chosen site out of 5 proposals. While opposition against the observatories on Mauna Kea has been ongoing since the first telescope this protest may be the most vocal. The project was expected to be completed by 2024, nearly simultaneously with the 39-meter [[Extremely Large Telescope]] being built in Chile however, on December 2, 2015, the [[Supreme Court of Hawaii]] invalidated the TMT's building permits. The court ruled that [[due process]] was not followed. The TMT corporation then removed all construction equipment and vehicles from Mauna Kea, and re-applied for a new permit, meant to respect the Supreme Court's ruling. This was granted on September 28, 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.maunakeaandtmt.org/hawaii-board-of-land-and-natural-resources-approves-conservation-district-use-permit-to-build-tmt-on-maunakea/|title=Hawaii Board of Land and Natural Resources Approves Conservation District Use Permit to Build TMT on Maunakea|date=Sep 29, 2017|accessdate=Nov 1, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://bigislandnow.com/2017/09/28/hawaii-blnr-approved-tmt-permit/|title=Hawai‘i BLNR Approves TMT Permit|website=Big Island Now|date=September 28, 2017|accessdate=November 1, 2018}}</ref> On October 30, 2018, the Court validated the new construction permit.<ref name="bbc201810313">[https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-46046864 Hawaii top court approves controversial Thirty Meter Telescope] BBC News, 2018-10-31.</ref>
==Background== {{main|Opposition to the Mauna Kea Observatories}}
===Development of Mauna Kea observatories=== After studying photos for NASA's [[Apollo program]] that contained greater detail than any ground based telescope, [[Gerard Kuiper]] began seeking an arid site for infrared studies.<ref name="Zirker2005" /><ref name="Inc.1964">{{cite book|author=Educational Foundation for Nuclear Science, Inc.|title=Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8gcAAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA35|date=November 1964|publisher=Educational Foundation for Nuclear Science, Inc.|page=35|issn=0096-3402}}</ref> While he first began looking in Chile, he also made the decision to perform tests in the Hawaiian Islands. Tests on [[Maui]]'s [[Haleakalā]] were promising but the mountain was too low in the inversion layer and often covered by clouds. On the "Big Island" of Hawaii, Mauna Kea is considered the highest island mountain in the world. While the summit is often covered with snow the air itself is extremely dry.<ref name="Zirker2005" /> Kuiper began looking into the possibility of an observatory on Mauna Kea. After testing, he discovered the low humidity was perfect for infrared signals. He persuaded then Governor, [[John A. Burns]] to bulldoze a dirt road to the summit where he built a small telescope on Pu{{okina}}u Poli{{okina}}ahu, a cinder cone peak.<ref name="Zirker2005" /><ref name="Yount1996">{{cite book|author=David Yount|title=Who Runs the University?: The Politics of Higher Education in Hawaii, 1985-1992|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZtnBE9CcxOAC&pg=PA232|date=1 January 1996|publisher=University of Hawaii Press|isbn=978-0-8248-1821-0|page=232}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Astronomy Now|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CB7yAAAAMAAJ|year=1991|publisher=Intra Press|page=45}}</ref> The peak was the second highest on the mountain with the highest peak being holy ground, so Kuiper avoided it.<ref name="PARKER2013">{{cite book|author=Barry R. PARKER|title=Stairway to the Stars: The Story of the World’s Largest Observatory|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RbkACAAAQBAJ&pg=PA25|date=11 November 2013|publisher=Springer|isbn=978-1-4899-6052-8|page=25}}</ref> Next, Kuiper tried enlisting NASA to fund a larger facility with a large telescope, housing and other needed structures. NASA, in turn decided to make the project open to competition. Professor of physics, John Jefferies of the [[University of Hawaii]] placed a bid on behalf of the university.<ref name="Zirker2005" /><ref name="Leverington2012">{{cite book|author=David Leverington|title=A History of Astronomy: from 1890 to the Present|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=r47qBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA276|date=6 December 2012|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media|isbn=978-1-4471-2124-4|page=276}}</ref><ref name="KaminsPotter1998">{{cite book|author1=Robert M. Kamins|author2=Robert E. Potter|author3=University of Hawaii (System)|title=Måalamalama: A History of the University of Hawai'i|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Q8jyzfUmFvgC&pg=PA211|date=January 1998|publisher=University of Hawaii Press|isbn=978-0-8248-2006-0|pages=210–211}}</ref> Jefferies had gained his reputation through observations at [[Sacramento Peak Observatory]]. The proposal was for a two-meter telescope to serve both the needs of NASA and the university. While large telescopes are not ordinarily awarded to universities without well established astronomers, Jefferies and UH were awarded the NASA contract infuriating Kuiper who felt that "his mountain" had been "stolen" from "him".<ref name="Zirker2005" /><ref name="Tatarewicz1990">{{cite book|author=Joseph N. Tatarewicz|title=Space Technology & Planetary Astronomy|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MnXQtlBcRFIC&pg=PA82|year=1990|publisher=Indiana University Press|isbn=0-253-35655-5|page=82}}</ref> Kuiper would abandon his site (the very first telecope on Mauna Kea) over the competition and begin work in Arizona on a different NASA project. After considerable testing by Jefferies' team, the best locations were determined to be near the summit at the top of the cinder cones. Testing also determined Mauna Kea to be superb for nighttime viewing due to many factors including the thin air, constant trade winds and being surrounded by sea. Jefferies would build a 2.24 meter telescope with the State of Hawaii agreeing to build a reliable, all weather roadway to the summit. Building began in 1967 and first light seen in 1970.<ref name="Zirker2005">{{cite book|author=J. B. Zirker|title=An Acre of Glass: A History and Forecast of the Telescope|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TYYVXIePsy4C&pg=PA94|date=18 October 2005|publisher=JHU Press|isbn=978-0-8018-8234-0|pages=89–95}}</ref>
===Observatory opposition=== Opposition to the observatories has existed since 1964.<ref name=Forbes>{{cite news|last1=Knapp|first1=Alex|title=Understanding The Thirty Meter Telescope Controversy|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/alexknapp/2015/06/12/understanding-the-thirty-meter-telescope-controversy/|accessdate=5 August 2015|agency=Forbes|publisher=Forbes|date=Jun 12, 2015}}</ref> In Honolulu, the governor and legislature, enthusiastic about the development, set aside an even larger area for the observatory causing opposition in the city of [[Hilo, Hawaii|Hilo]]. Native [[kānaka ʻōiwi]] believed the entire site was sacred and that developing the mountain, even for science, would spoil the area. Environmentalists were concerned about rare native bird populations and other citizens of Hilo were concerned about the sight of the domes from the city. Using town hall meetings, Jefferies was able to overcome opposition by weighing the economic advantage and prestige the island would receive.<ref name="Zirker2005" />Over the years, the opposition to the observatories may have become the most visible example of the conflict science has encountered over access and use of environmental and culturally significant sites.<ref name="DearKetchum2011">{{cite book|author1=Michael Dear|author2=Jim Ketchum|author3=Sarah Luria |author4=Doug Richardson |title=GeoHumanities: Art, History, Text at the Edge of Place|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zwrJBQAAQBAJ&pg=PT476|date=13 April 2011|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-136-88347-7|page=476}}</ref> Opposition to development grew shortly after expansion of the observatories commenced. Once access was opened up by the roadway to the summit, skiers began using it for recreation and objected when the road was closed as a precaution against vandalism when the telescopes were being built. Hunters voiced concerns as did the Hawaiian [[Audubon Society]] who were supported by Governor [[George Ariyoshi]].<ref name="PARKER2013b">{{cite book|author=Barry R. PARKER|title=Stairway to the Stars: The Story of the World’s Largest Observatory|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RbkACAAAQBAJ&pg=PA56|date=11 November 2013|publisher=Springer|isbn=978-1-4899-6052-8|page=56}}</ref>
The Audubon Society objected to further development on Mauna Kea over concerns to habitat of the endangered [[palila]], an [[endemic]] species to only specific parts of this mountain. The bird is the last of the finch billed honeycreepers existing on the island. Over 50% of native bird species had been killed off due to loss of habitat from early western settlers or the introduction of non native species competing for resources. Hunters and sportsmen were concerned that the hunting of feral animals would be affected by the telescope operations.<ref name="Gordon2007">{{cite book|author=Mark Gordon|title=Recollections of "Tucson Operations": The Millimeter-Wave Observatory of the National Radio Astronomy Observatory|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iWPbIrwEKpMC&pg=PA136|date=18 July 2007|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media|isbn=978-1-4020-3236-3|pages=136–140}}</ref> A "Save Mauna Kea" movement was inspired by the proliferation of telescopes with opposition believing development of the mountain to be sacrilegious.<ref name="Oaks2003">{{cite book|author=Robert F. Oaks|title=Hawaii:: A History of the Big Island|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HDVNJ5wzcisC&pg=PA131|date=1 November 2003|publisher=Arcadia Publishing|isbn=978-1-4396-1403-7|page=131}}</ref> Native Hawaiian non-profit groups such as [[Kahea]], whose goals are the protection of cultural heritage and the environment, oppose development on Mauna Kea as a sacred space to the Hawaiian religion.<ref name="Kaufman2009">{{cite book|author=Ned Kaufman|title=Place, Race, and Story: Essays on the Past and Future of Historic Preservation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5fCTAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA14|date=11 September 2009|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-135-88972-2|page=14}}</ref> Today, Mauna Kea hosts the world's largest location for telescope observations in infrared and submillimeter astronomy. The land itself is protected by the US Historical Preservation Act due to its significance to Hawaiian culture but still allowed development.<ref name="Schachter2013">{{cite book|author=Judith Schachter|title=The Legacies of a Hawaiian Generation: From Territorial Subject to American Citizen|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OTTUAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA43|date=15 September 2013|publisher=Berghahn Books|isbn=978-1-78238-012-2|page=43}}</ref>
===Outrigger telescopes=== Further development of the Mauna Kea observatories is still opposed by environmental groups and Native Hawaiians. A 2006 proposal for the [[Navy Precision Optical Interferometer|Outrigger Telescopes]] to become extensions of the [[Keck Observatory]] was canceled after a judges determination that a full environmental impact statement must be prepared before any further development of the site.<ref name="Campbell2010">{{cite book|author=Jeff Campbell|title=Hawaii|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TRXR69wo-rYC&pg=PA97|date=15 September 2010|publisher=Lonely Planet|isbn=978-1-74220-344-7|page=97}}</ref> The "outrigger" would have linked the [[Keck I]] and [[Keck II]] telescopes. Environmental groups and Native Hawaiian activist were a lot stronger at this time than in the past but NASA went ahead with the proposal for lack of an alternate site. The group ''Mauna Kea Anaina Hou'' made several arguments against the development including that Mauna Kea was a sacred mountain to Native Hawaiians where many deities had lived, and that the cinder cone being proposed as the site was holy in Hawaiian tradition as a burial site for a demi-god. The group raised several other concerns such as environmental over native insects, the question of [[Ceded lands]] and an audit report, critical of the mountain's management.<ref name="Takahashi2008">{{cite book|author=Patrick Kenji Takahashi|title=Simple Solutions for Humanity|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sNBF9eqXUzYC&pg=PA164|date=29 February 2008|publisher=AuthorHouse|isbn=978-1-4678-3517-6|page=164}}</ref>
===Thirty Meter Telescope proposal=== [[File:Kealoha Pisciotta.JPG|left|thumb|Kealoha Pisciotta, a former Mauna Kea Observatory employee, testifies at a State hearing in 2011]] The Thirty Meter Telescope (TMT) is a proposed extremely large, segmented mirror telescope, planned for the summit of Mauna Kea. It is now the focal point of further development of the observatory site, with a current ongoing legal battle in the Hawaii court system. The proposal continues to spawn a great deal of controversy over the use of the site for science.<ref name="Fullagar2012">{{cite book|author=Kate Fullagar|title=The Atlantic World in the Antipodes: Effects and Transformations since the Eighteenth Century|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ET4sBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA71|date=15 March 2012|publisher=Cambridge Scholars Publishing|isbn=978-1-4438-3806-1|pages=70–71}}</ref>
The TMT project is a response to recommendation in 2000 from the [[US National Academy of Sciences]] that a thirty-meter telescope be a top priority, and that it be built within the decade.<ref name="LobanovZensus2007">{{cite book|author1=A.P. Lobanov|author2=J.A. Zensus|author3=C. Cesarsky |author4=Ph. Diamond |title=Exploring the Cosmic Frontier: Astrophysical Instruments for the 21st Century|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UyltC13KR-4C&pg=PA24|date=15 February 2007|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media|isbn=978-3-540-39756-4|page=24}}</ref> Urgency in construction is due to the competitive nature of science with the [[European-Extremely Large Telescope]] also under construction.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.latimes.com/science/sciencenow/la-sci-sn-tmt-30-meter-telescope-20141006-story.html | title=Monster telescope breaks ground, will offer deepest views of universe | date=October 7, 2014 | agency=[[Los Angeles Times]] | accessdate=21 April 2015 | author=Hubbard, Amy}}</ref> The two projects are also complementary, in that the EELT would only view the [[Southern Celestial Hemisphere]], while Mauna Kea offers the best views of the [[Northern Celestial Hemisphere]]. However, Mauna Kea's summit is considered the most sacred of all the mountains in Hawaii to many [[Native Hawaiian people]].<ref name="Hendreschke">{{cite book|author=Sabine Hendreschke|title=Menehune Mana The Spiritual Essence of Hawaii|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PPy-z3wG9AkC&pg=PT43|publisher=Sabine Hendreschke|page=43|id=GGKEY:PDSF05H9RAT}}</ref><ref name="GrayHancock2007">{{cite book|author1=Martin Gray|author2=Graham Hancock|title=Sacred Earth: Places of Peace and Power|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RmBcIDvf6XEC&pg=PA254|year=2007|publisher=Sterling Pub.Company|isbn=978-1-4027-4737-3|page=254}}</ref><ref name="YamamotoTarbell2005">{{cite book|author1=Luci Yamamoto|author2=Alan Tarbell|title=Hawai'i: The Big Island|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=T83kOvN6aTYC&pg=PA137|year=2005|publisher=Lonely Planet|isbn=978-1-74059-691-6|page=137}}</ref> Native Hawaiian activists such as Kealoha Pisciotta, a former employee of the [[Mauna Kea Observatories]], have raised concerns over the perceived desecration of Mauna Kea posed by TMT construction and presence.<ref name="LaDuke2005">{{cite book|author=[[Winona LaDuke]]|title=Recovering the Sacred: The Power of Naming and Claiming|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8je1uCLLRvgC&pg=PA30|year=2005|publisher=South End Press|isbn=978-0-89608-712-5|pages=30–31}}</ref> Pisciotta, a former telescope systems specialist technician at [[James Clerk Maxwell Telescope]], is one of several people suing to stop the construction<ref name=Worth>{{cite news|last1=Worth|first1=Katie|title=World’s Largest Telescope Faces Opposition from Native Hawaiian Protesters|url=http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/world-s-largest-telescope-faces-opposition-from-native-hawaiian-protesters/|accessdate=22 April 2015|agency=Scientific American|publisher=Scientific American, a Division of Nature America, Inc.|date=February 20, 2015}}</ref> and is also director of Mauna Kea Anaina Hou.<ref name="Huliau">{{cite book|title=Huliau: Time of Change|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_torGEMuDyYC|date=1 January 2004|publisher=Kuleana 'Oiwi Press|isbn=978-0-9668220-3-8}}</ref> However, some native Hawaiians do support the TMT project, including Peter Apo, a sitting trustee of the Office of Hawaiian Affairs.<ref name=Estrellon>{{cite news|last1=Estrellon|first1=April|title=Pod Squad: The TMT Battle and the Native Hawaiian Leadership Void|url=http://www.civilbeat.com/2015/08/pod-squad-the-tmt-battle-and-the-native-hawaiian-leadership-void/|accessdate=18 September 2015|agency=CivilBeat|date=August 15, 2015}}</ref>
As of April, 2015, two separate legal appeals were still pending.<ref name=NPR>{{cite news|last1=Solomon|first1=Molly|title=Construction Of Giant Telescope In Hawaii Draws Natives' Ire|url=https://www.npr.org/2015/04/21/400390724/construction-of-giant-telescope-in-hawaii-draws-natives-ire|agency=National Public Radio|publisher=NPR|date=April 21, 2015}}</ref>
The 1998 study ''Mauna Kea Science Reserve and Hale Pohaku Complex Development Plan Update'' stated that "... nearly all the interviewees and all others who participated in the consultation process (Appendices B and C) called for a moratorium on any further development on the summit of Mauna Kea".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.envirowatch.org/MKoverview.htm |title=overview of info |work= Mauna Kea Science Reserve and Hale Pohaku Complex Development Plan Update:|accessdate=April 20, 2015}}</ref> Native Hawaiians and environmentalists are opposed to any further telescopes.<ref name="Huliau" />
The [[Hawai'i Department of Land and Natural Resources|Hawaii Board of Land and Natural Resources]] conditionally approved the Mauna Kea site for the TMT in February 2011. While the approval has been challenged, the Board officially approved the site following a hearing on April 12, 2013.<ref name="news1">{{cite news| url= http://www.3news.co.nz/Massive-telescope-to-be-built-in-Hawaii/tabid/1160/articleID/294296/Default.aspx|work=3 News NZ |title= Massive telescope to be built in Hawaii| date=April 15, 2013}}</ref>
===Indigenous peoples rights=== The issue of native peoples, their religious freedom and rights in regards to authority for large science-based projects has become a major issue to contend with. [[Mt. Graham]] had an issue with the sanctity of the mountain raised by activists. Observatories have succeeded in being built, but only after protracted and expensive litigation and effort.
==Blockade and protests== [[File:Joshua Lanakila Mangauil, Thirty Meter Telescope protest, October 7, 2014.jpg|thumb|Hawaiian [[Cultural practice|cultural practitioner]], Joshua Lanakila Mangauil interrupted the TMT ground breaking on October 7, 2014]]
===Roadway blockade and ground breaking interruption=== On October 7, 2014 the groundbreaking for the telescope was being live streamed via webcam. The proceedings were interrupted when the official caravan encountered several dozen demonstrators picketing and chanting in the middle of the roadway. A planned ceremony at the base of the mountain was scheduled by the group, ''Mauna Kea Anaina Hou'', in opposition of the telescope<ref name="Kelleher" /> and in a press release dated that day, the organization Sacred Mauna Kea stated: "Native Hawaiians and non-Hawaiians will gather for a peaceful protest against the Astronomy industry and the State of Hawaii’s ground-breaking ceremony for a thirty-meter telescope (TMT) on the summit of Mauna Kea."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Sacred Mauna Kea|title=Press Release: Hawaiians Protest 30-meter telescope on Mauna Kea, October 7th|url=http://dgrnewsservice.org/2014/10/07/press-release-hawaiians-protest-30-meter-telescope-on-mauna-kea-october-7th/|accessdate=23 April 2015|agency=Deep Green Resistance News Service|publisher=[[Deep Green Resistance]] News Service|date=October 7, 2014}}</ref> Several members traveled up the mountain and were stopped by police, where they laid down in the road and blocked the caravan. The nonviolent protest did not stop or block any people but when the ceremony for the ground breaking began, protesters interrupted the blessing, stopping the proceedings as well as the groundbreaking.<ref name="Kelleher">{{cite news|last1=Kelleher|first1=Jennifer Sinco|title=Protesters halt Mauna Kea telescope groundbreaking|url=http://www.staradvertiser.com/news/breaking/20141007_Groundbreaking_delayed_for_Hawaii_telescope.html?id=278448831|accessdate=4 April 2015|agency=Honolulu Star Advertiser|publisher=staradvertiser.com|date=October 7, 2014}}</ref>
That same day in California, protesters demonstrated outside the headquarters of the [[Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation]] in [[Palo Alto, CA]].<ref name=Mai>{{cite news|last1=Mai|first1=E. Komo|title=VIDEO: Full Coverage of Thirty Meter Telescope Disruption|url=http://www.bigislandvideonews.com/2014/10/09/video-full-coverage-thirty-meter-telescope-road-block/|accessdate=23 April 2015|agency=Big Island Video News|publisher=Big Island Video News|date=October 9, 2014}}</ref><ref name=Cooper>{{cite news|last1=Cooper|first1=Jeanne|title=Peaceful protest in Palo Alto against massive Mauna Kea telescope|url=http://blog.sfgate.com/hawaii/2014/10/07/peaceful-protest-in-palo-alto-against-massive-mauna-kea-telescope/|accessdate=23 April 2015|agency=SFGATE|publisher=SFGATE|date=October 7, 2014}}</ref>
===Second Mauna Kea blockade and arrests, 2015=== Beginning in late March 2015 demonstrators halted construction crews near the visitors center, again by blocking access of the road to the summit of the mountain. Heavy equipment had already been placed near the site. Daniel Meisenzahl, a spokesman for the University of Hawaii, stated that the 5 tractors trailers of equipment that were moved up the mountain the day before had alerted protesters that began organizing the demonstrations. Kamahana Kealoha of the group Sacred Mauna Kea stated that over 100 demonstrators had traveled up to the summit to camp overnight, to be joined by more protesters in the early morning to blockade crews.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Davis|first1=Chelsea|title=Thirty Meter Telescope protesters continue to block construction on Mauna Kea|url=http://www.hawaiinewsnow.com/story/28619239/thirty-meter-telescope-protesters-continue-to-block-construction-on-mauna-kea|accessdate=4 April 2015|agency=KHNL|publisher=WorldNow and KHNL|date=March 26, 2015}}</ref> On April 2, 2015, 300 protesters were gathered near the visitor's center where 12 people were arrested. 11 more protesters were arrested at the summit.<ref name="usnews1">{{cite news|title=Clash in Hawaii Between Science and Sacred Land|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/science/news/articles/2015/04/03/clash-over-telescope-at-sacred-hawaiian-site-intensifies|accessdate=4 April 2015|agency=Associated Press|publisher=AP/US News and World Report|date=April 3, 2015}}</ref> Protesters, ranging in age from 27 to 75 years of age were handcuffed and led away by local police.<ref>{{cite news|title=Police, TMT Issue Statements on Mass Arrests on Mauna Kea|url=http://www.bigislandvideonews.com/2015/04/02/police-tmt-issue-statements-on-mass-arrests-on-mauna-kea/|accessdate=4 April 2015|agency=Big Island Video News|publisher=Big Island Video News|date=April 2, 2015}}</ref> Among the major concerns of the protest groups is whether the land appraisals were done accurately and that Native Hawaiians were not consulted. When the trucks were finally allowed to pass, protesters followed the procession up the summit. A project spokesman said that work had begun after arrests were made and the road cleared.
Among the arrests was professional surfer and former candidate for mayor of [[Kauai]], Dustin Barca. A number of celebrity activists of Native Hawaiian descent, both local and national, began campaigning over social media, including ''[[Game of Thrones]]'' star [[Jason Momoa]] who urged [[Dwayne Johnson]] (The Rock) to join the protests with him on top of Mauna Kea.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Scheuring|first1=Ian|title=Local celebrities take to social media in Mauna Kea protests|url=http://www.hawaiinewsnow.com/story/28730585/more-arrests-reported-sunday-during-mauna-kea-protests|accessdate=9 April 2015|agency=WorldNow and KHNL|publisher=Hawaii News Now|date=April 6, 2015}}</ref> Construction was halted for one week at the request of Hawaii state governor [[David Ige]] on April 7, 2015 after the protest on Mauna Kea continued and demonstrations began to appear over the state. Project Manager, Gary Sanders stated that TMT agreed to the one-week stop for continued dialogue. Kealoha Pisciotta, president of ''Mauna Kea Anaina Hou'' viewed the development as positive but said opposition to the project would continue.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.usnews.com/news/science/news/articles/2015/04/07/amid-controversy-construction-of-telescope-in-hawaii-halted |title=Amid controversy, construction of telescope in Hawaii halted - US News |format= |work= |accessdate=April 7, 2015}}</ref> Pisciotta also stated that the protests would continue to be within a [[Kapu Aloha]]; ''"moving in Aloha with steadfast determination"''.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Wang|first1=Frances Kai-Hwa|title=Native Hawaiians Arrested in Protests of Massive Telescope|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/asian-america/native-hawaiians-arrested-protests-massive-telescope-n336176|accessdate=10 October 2015|agency=NBC News|publisher=NBC News|date=April 6, 2015}}</ref>
===Temporary halt=== Governor Ige announced that the project was being temporarily postponed until at least April 20, 2015.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Yoro|first1=Sarah|title=Thirty Meter Telescope construction delayed|url=http://khon2.com/2015/04/11/thirty-meter-telescope-construction-delayed/|accessdate=15 April 2015|agency=KHON2|publisher=LIN Television Corporation, a Media General company|date=April 11, 2015}}</ref> In response to the growing protests the TMT Corporation's division of Hawaii Community Affairs launched an internet microsite, updating content regularly.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hawaii's Thirty Meter Telescope launches informational microsite online|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/pacific/blog/2015/04/hawaiis-thirty-meter-telescope-launches.html|accessdate=17 April 2015|agency=Pacific Business News|publisher=American City Business Journals|date=April 14, 2015}}</ref> The company also took to social media to respond to the opposition's growing momentum by hiring public relations firms to assist as the company's voice in the islands.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Gill|first1=Lorin Eleni|title=Thirty Meter Telescope project in Hawaii responds to opposition with website, social media|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/pacific/blog/2015/04/thirty-meter-telescope-project-in-hawaii-responds.html|accessdate=17 April 2015|agency=Pacific Business news|publisher=American City Business Journals|date=April 16, 2015}}</ref> TMT sublease payments on hold following order for a contested case hearing.<ref>http://www.bizjournals.com/pacific/news/2017/02/06/thirty-meter-telescopes-sublease-payments-on-hold.html</ref>
[[File:Thirty Meter Telescope protest, October 7, 2014.jpg|thumb|Demonstrators call themselves protectors, not protestors]]
==Continued local demonstrations== The protests sparked statewide, national as well as international attention to Hawaiian culture, Mauna Kea and the 45-year history of 13 other telescopes on the mountain.
At the University of Hawaii Manoa, hundreds of students lined the streets for blocks and, one by one, they passed the stones from the student taro patch of the university's Center on Hawaiian Studies down the human chain to the lawn in front of the office university president, David Lassner, where the stones were used to build an ''ahu'' (the altar of a ''[[heiau]]'') as a message to the university.<ref name=Garcia>{{cite news|last1=Garcia|first1=Nester|title=Hundreds form chain at UH Manoa to protest Thirty Meter Telescope|url=http://khon2.com/2015/04/10/hundreds-form-chain-at-uh-manoa-to-protest-thirty-meter-telescope-3/|accessdate=22 April 2015|agency=KHON2|publisher=LIN Television Corporation, a Media General company|date=April 10, 2015}}</ref>
On April 21, 2015, hundreds of protesters filled the streets of [[Honolulu]] protesting against the TMT.<ref name="Witze2015">{{cite journal|last1=Witze|first1=Alexandra|title=Hawaiian telescope project seeks way forward amid protests|journal=Nature|year=2015|issn=1476-4687|doi=10.1038/nature.2015.17396}}</ref>
==Permit invalidated== On December 2, 2015, the Supreme Court of Hawaii invalidated the TMT's building permits, ruling that [[due process]] was not followed when the Board of Land and Natural Resources approved the permit before the [[contested case hearing]]. The TMT company [[chairman]] stated: ''"T.M.T. will follow the process set forth by the state..".''<ref>{{cite news|last1=Overbye|first1=Dennis|title=Contested case hearing|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/12/04/science/space/hawaii-court-rescinds-permit-to-build-thirty-meter-telescope.html?_r=0|accessdate=18 December 2015|agency=The New York Times|publisher=The New York Times|date=December 3, 2015}}</ref><ref>http://www.courts.state.hi.us/docs/opin_ord/sct/2015/December/SCAP-14-0000873.pdf</ref> On December 16, the TMT corporation began removal of all construction equipment and vehicles from Mauna Kea.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Epping|first1=Jamilia|title=TMT Equipment Removal Underway|url=http://bigislandnow.com/2015/12/16/tmt-equipment-removal-underway/|accessdate=20 December 2015|agency=Big Island Now|publisher=Big Island Now|date=December 16, 2015}}</ref>
==Permit approved== On September 28, 2017, the Hawaii Board of Land and Natural Resources approved the TMT's Conservation District Use Permit.<ref>[https://dlnr.hawaii.gov/blog/2017/09/28/nr17-0153/ 09/28/17 – Board of Land and Natural Resources Approves TMT Permit]</ref> On October 30, 2018, the Supreme Court of Hawaii validated the construction permit.<ref name="bbc201810313" />

{{Infobox women |image = Michele Bachelet (2009).jpg |caption = [[Michele Bachelet]], who served as the first woman [[President of Chile]] from 2006 to 2010. |gii = 0.360 (2012) |gii_rank = 66th |matdeath = 25 (2010) |womparl = 15.8% (2014) |femed = 72.1% (2010) |womlab = 52% [[employment rate]], data from [[OECD]], 2016 <ref name="stats.oecd.org">{{cite web|url=http://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DatasetCode=LFS_SEXAGE_I_R#|author=OECD|publisher=stats.oecd.org|title=LFS by sex and age - indicators|accessdate=13 March 2017}}</ref> | ggg = 0.6670 (2013) | ggg_rank = 91st | ggg_ref = <ref name="ggr">{{cite web|title=The Global Gender Gap Report 2013|url=http://www3.weforum.org/docs/WEF_GenderGap_Report_2013.pdf#page=20|publisher=World Economic Forum|pages=12–13}}</ref> }} {{Women in society sidebar}} The lives, roles, and rights of '''women in Chile''' have gone through many changes over time. Chilean women's societal roles have historically been impacted by traditional [[gender roles]] and a [[patriarchy|patriarchal culture]], but throughout the twentieth century, women increasingly involved themselves in [[politics]] and [[protest]], resulting in provisions to the [[constitution]] to uphold equality between men and women and prohibit [[Sexism|sex discrimination]].
Women's educational attainment, workforce participation, and rights have improved, especially since [[Chile]] became a [[democracy]] again in 1990. Chile legalized [[divorce]] in 2004 and is also one of the few countries to have elected a [[Michelle Bachelet|female president]].<ref name=SIGI>{{cite web|title=Gender Equality and Social Institutions in Chile|url=http://genderindex.org/country/chile|publisher=Social Institutions and Gender Index|accessdate=31 March 2012}}</ref> However, Chilean women still face many economic and political challenges, including [[economic inequality|income disparity]], high rates of [[domestic violence]], and lingering gender roles.
==History of women== {{See|History of Chile|Feminism in Chile}} [[File:María de la Cruz Toledo.jpg|thumb|200 px|[[María de la Cruz]], (1912–1995), Chilean political activist for [[women's suffrage]], journalist, writer, and political commentator. In 1953, she became the first woman ever elected to the Chilean Senate]] Women were granted the right to vote in 1931 and 1949 during Chile's [[Presidential Republic (1925-1973)|presidential era]].<ref name=dandavati /><ref name="mujeres que hacen historia" /> Also during the era, thousands of women protested against [[socialist]] [[president]] [[Salvador Allende]] in the March of the Empty Pots and Pans.<ref name="power"/> While under [[Augusto Pinochet]]'s authoritarian regime, women also participated in ''las protestas'', protests against Allende's plebiscite in which women voted "no."<ref name="dandavati"/> During Chile's time under [[dictator]] Pinochet, the state of women's legal rights fell behind most of [[Latin America]], even though Chile had one of the strongest economies in [[South America]].<ref name=haas>{{cite book|last=Haas|first=Liesl|title=Feminist Policymaking in Chile|year=2010|publisher=The Pennsylvania State University Press|location=University Park, Pennsylvania|isbn=978-0-271-03746-2}}</ref> Chile returned to [[democracy]] in 1990, leading to changes in women's lives and roles within society.<ref name="StangeOyster2011"/> Since the return to democracy, Chile's government has invested more political and economic resources to expand social welfare programs than before.<ref name=Pribble>{{cite journal|title=Women and Welfare|journal=Latin American Research Review|date=June 2006|volume=41|issue=2|author=Jennifer Pribble}}</ref> The ''[[Coalition of Parties for Democracy|Concertación]]'' political party has been in power since the end of Pinochet's dictatorship, and from 2006 to 2010, [[Michelle Bachelet]] of the party served as the first female [[President of Chile]].<ref name=Econ1>{{cite web|last=|first=|title=Women in Chile: Left behind|url=http://www.economist.com/node/7281220|work=[[The Economist]]|accessdate=24 February 2012|date=10 August 2006}}</ref><ref name=Santiago1>{{cite web|last=Shea|first=Steve|title=Setting quotas in Chile for women in politics|url=http://santiagotimes.cl/setting-quotas-in-chile-for-women-in-politics/|work=[[Santiago Times]]|accessdate=24 February 2012|date=13 December 2011}}</ref>
===Women in society=== Chile has been described as one of the most [[socially conservative]] countries of Latin America.<ref name="bbc">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-18546587|publisher=bbc.com|title=Changing times in Chile? - BBC News|accessdate=13 March 2017}}</ref><ref name="nytimes">{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/12/16/world/americas/bachelet-wins-chilean-presidency-in-landslide.html?_r=0|publisher=nytimes.com|title=Chilean Voters Return a Former President to Power - The New York Times|accessdate=13 March 2017}}</ref><ref name="telegraph">{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/southamerica/chile/10170520/Chiles-president-praises-11-year-old-for-going-ahead-with-pregnancy-resulting-from-rape.html|publisher=telegraph.co.uk|title=Chile's president praises 11-year-old for going ahead with pregnancy resulting from rape - Telegraph|accessdate=13 March 2017}}</ref> In comparison to the United States, Chile did not have so many feminists among its evolution of women's intrusion to the political sphere. Chilean women esteemed [[Roman Catholicism in Chile|Catholicism]] as their rites of passage, which initiated women's movements in opposition to the liberal political party's eruption in the Chilean government. The traditional domesticated setting that women were accustomed to was used as a patriarchal reasoning for women's restriction of women's votes. However, Chileans religious convictions as devout Catholics initiated their desire to vote against the adamant anticlerical liberal party. In 1875, [[Domitila Silva Y Lepe]], the widow of a former provincial governor, read the requirements deeming "all adult Chileans the right to vote", and was the first woman to vote.<ref name="books.google.com">{{cite book|title=Right-Wing Women in Chile: Feminine Power and the Struggle Against Allende, 1964-1973|author=Power, M.|date=2010|publisher=Pennsylvania State University Press|isbn=9780271046716|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=Wq1yTZBHSiAC&pg=PA49|page=49|accessdate=13 March 2017}}</ref> Other elitist Chilean women followed her bold lead, which resulted in the anticlerical liberal party of congress to pass a law denying women the right to vote. Despite this set back, Ms. Lepe and other elite women expressed their religious standings to the conservative party. The conservative party were favorable of the women because they knew their support would influence the conservative party's domination in politics. In [[1912 Social Catholicism]] began to erupt.<ref name="books.google.com"/> Social Catholicism- upper class women's organization of working class women-was led by Amalia Errazuriz de Subercaseaux. She introduced the Liga de Damas Chilenas (League of Chilean Ladies) amongst 450 other upper-middle class women with intentions to "uphold and defend the interests of those women who worked for a living without attacking the principles of order and authority". Following this organization, many other elite women began socially constructed women's institutions. [[Amanda Labarca]] was also an elitist, but disagreed with the privileged women's subjection of working class women and founded the ladies reading club.<ref name="books.google.com"/> She believed women should be educated, regardless of their socioeconomic status to have a more influentially productive role in society.
===Gender roles=== Traditional [[gender role]] beliefs are prevalent in Chilean society, specifically the ideas that women should focus on motherhood and be submissive to men.<ref name="HIV1"/> A 2010 study by the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) reported that 62 percent of Chileans are opposed to full gender equality. Many of those surveyed expressed the belief that women should limit themselves to the traditional roles of mother and wife.<ref name=Estrada2010>{{cite news|last=Estrada|first=Daniela|title=Gender Equity Progress Blocked by Hard-Core 'Machismo'|url=http://ipsnews.net/news.asp?idnews=51446|accessdate=24 February 2012|date=May 14, 2010|agency=Inter Press Service News Agency}}</ref> However, the 2012 World Development Report states that male attitudes toward gender equality are that "men do not lose out when women's rights are promoted."<ref name=WDR2012>{{cite book |title=Gender Equality and Development: World Development Report 2012|year=2012|publisher=The World Bank|location=Washington D.C.}}</ref>
===Motherhood=== Catholicism is embodied wholly among Chilean family identities. [[Virgin Mary]] is the idolized example of motherhood. Her pure and sacrificial acts are to be embodied by Chilean mothers.<ref name="google">{{cite book|title=Contesting Legitimacy in Chile: Familial Ideals, Citizenship, and Political Struggle, 1970-1990|author=Thomas, G.|date=2011|publisher=Pennsylvania State University Press|isbn=9780271048499|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=oC1sjIMEOC4C&pg=PA17|page=17|accessdate=13 March 2017}}</ref> Traditionally, women are supposed to be the connoisseurs of endurance like the Virgin Mary. The biblical significance is portrayed through the traditional government of Chile. In the early 1900s, the gendered examples among Catholicism were embodied by the patriarchal government and suffrage of women. Women were domesticated and confined to the home. In the late 1940s women's issues were embraced by [[First Lady Rosa Markman de Gonzalez Videla]] in acknowledgement of Mothers centers, women gaining access to resources to fulfill their role as housewives, encouraged women as consumers to fight against high living costs, and to raise their interest in partaking in other avenues of public life within the country, such as work and political participation.<ref name="google2">{{cite book|title=The Politics of Motherhood|author=Mooney, J.P.|date=2009|publisher=University of Pittsburgh Press|isbn=9780822973614|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=HnEKKaWjcyAC&pg=PA75|page=75|accessdate=13 March 2017}}</ref> The First Lady's efforts to advocate the evolution of women reform led to the modern techniques of the women reform. In the 1960s, campaigns for the Christian democrat, Frei, emphasized women and women's issues. Voting had just become mandatory for all Chileans and was the first time in history registration for female voters increased from thirty-five percent to seventy-five percent. The Christian democratic change of government opened women's access to birth control. However, the government's emphasis on the modernization of women institutions and underlying issues of gender hierarchy, women in poverty were neglected. Restrictions within the women's institutions, mother centers, restricted mothers under 18. To further structurally cripple Chilean women, first lady [[Maria Ruiz Tagle de Frei]] supervised "proper functioning" of feminist organizations.<ref name="google2"/> The Central Organization for Mothers [[(CEMA)]] was created as a formal structure to advise the underprivileged Chilean mothers.<ref name="google2"/> [[Carmen Gloria Aguayo]] revolutionized the mother's centers during the period of conflict between change and tradition during the Christian democrat campaign.<ref name="google2"/> Ms. Aguayo also headed the party's women's departments amongst forty-eight men and reflected the political direction of the initiatives: policies to protect the family- defending women's rights to work, to maternity leave, to equitable pay and occupation, a new opportunities for training and learning in the promised department for female labor studies. Because familial welfare was deemed important within the Chilean society, mothers have served as a political representation to have a voice in amongst the government.
==Legal rights== Currently, women have many of the same rights as men.<ref name=report/> The [[National Women's Service]] (SERNAM) is charged with protecting women's legal rights in the [[public sector]].<ref name=report/><ref name=WB>{{cite web|last=|first=|title=Chile: Reconciling the Gender Paradox|url=http://siteresources.worldbank.org/INTENBREVE/Newsletters/21455235/Apr07_105_GenderChile_EN.pdf|work=World Bank|accessdate=24 February 2012|date=April 2007}}</ref>
===Marriage=== Until recently, women lost their right to manage their own [[asset]]s once they were married<ref name=derechos>{{cite book|title=Género y derechos de las mujeres a la tierra en Chile|year=1999|publisher=Salgó Ltd.|isbn=956-7236-13-5|author=Magdalena León|author2=Carmen Diana Deere |language=Spanish}}</ref> and husbands received all of the wealth,<ref name="dandavati"/> but that law has since changed and women can now administer their own assets.<ref name="derechos"/> A couple can also sign a legal agreement before marriage so that all assets continue to be owned by the one who brought them into the marriage.<ref name="derechos"/>
The [[Chilean Civil Code]] previously mandated that wives had to live with and be faithful and obedient to their husbands, but it is no longer in the law.<ref name="dandavati"/> A married woman cannot be head of the household or head of the family in the same way as a man; however, married women are not required by law to obey their husbands.<ref name ="chile data"/>
====Divorce==== Chile legalized [[divorce]] in 2004, overturning an 1884 legal code.<ref name="bbc divorce">{{cite news|title=Chile introduces right to divorce|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/4021427.stm|newspaper=BBC News|date=November 18, 2004}}</ref> The law that legalizes divorce is the New Civil Marriage Law which was first introduced as a [[Bill (proposed law)|bill]] in 1995. There had been previous divorce bills before, but this one managed to secure enough conservative and liberal support to pass.<ref name="haas"/>
With divorce now being legal, four marital statuses exist within Chile: married, separated, divorced, and widow (er). Only the divorced and widow (er) statuses allow a new marriage.<ref name="chile government divorce">{{cite web|title=How to Get Married or Divorced|url=http://chileabroad.gov.cl/en/que-hacer/para-casarse-o-separarse/|publisher=Gobierno de Chile|accessdate=11 April 2012|author=Ministerio de Relaciones Exteriores}}</ref> Before the legalization of divorce, the only way to leave a marriage was to obtain a civil [[annulment]] which would only be granted by telling the civil registrar that the spouse had lied in some way concerning the marriage license, thereby voiding the marriage contract.<ref name="haas"/>
===Property=== In marriage, there are three types of assets: those of the husband, those of the wife, and the common assets that pertain to both. Land and houses in a marriage continue to be the property of the person who brought them to the marriage, but in order to sell them, both the husband and wife must sign.<ref name="derechos"/> In the case of divorce, both the man and woman are entitled to ownership of the marital home.<ref name="chile data"/> In the case of the death of a spouse, the surviving spouse, regardless of gender, has equal inheritance rights to the marital home.<ref name="chile data"/> If there is no will when the husband dies, the wife is given an equal category as the children for inheritance.<ref name="derechos"/> Before marriage, a couple can sign a legal document separating all assets so that the woman and man each administer her or his own; in this case, the husband cannot control his wife's assets.<ref name="derechos"/>
If women work outside the home independent of their husbands, acquire personal assets, and can prove that they came by these assets through their independent work, then these working women can accumulate these assets as their own, unable to be touched by husbands.<ref name="derechos"/>
Sons and daughters have equal inheritance rights to [[personal property|moveable]] and [[immovable property]] from their parents.<ref name="chile data">{{cite web|title=Women, business, and the law: creating economic opportunity for women|url=http://wbl.worldbank.org/data/exploreeconomies/chile/2011?topic=using-property|publisher=The World Bank|accessdate=18 March 2012|authorlink=Chile|year=2011}}</ref> Unmarried men and women have equal ownership rights to moveable and immoveable property.<ref name="chile data"/>
In rural Chile, inheritance is the principle way in which land is acquired by both men and women, whether the land has [[Title (property)|titles]] or not.<ref name="derechos"/> Sometimes women cannot claim their inheritance to land without titles because the cost of legal documents is too high.<ref name="derechos"/>
===Suffrage=== Women were granted the right to vote in municipal elections in 1931<ref name=dandavati>{{cite book|last=Dandavati|first=Annie G.|title=The Women's Movement and the Transition to Democracy in Chile|year=1996|publisher=Peter Lang Publishing, Inct.|location=New York|isbn=0-8204-2562-1}}</ref> and obtained the right to vote in national elections on January 8, 1949, resulting in their ability to vote under the same equal conditions as men and increasing women's participation in politics.<ref name="mujeres que hacen historia">{{cite book|title=Mujeres que hacen historia|year=2005|publisher=[[LOM Ediciones]]|isbn=956-282-724-0|author=Ximena Galleguillos|author2=Diana Veneros |author3=Carmen Ortuzar |author4=Arnoldo Carreras |page=5}}</ref>
===Family law=== Both Chilean men and women qualify for a [[Child benefit|family allowance]] if they have dependent children under the age of eighteen (or twenty-four if in school). There are differences in entitlement requirements for the spouse-related family allowance since a man qualifies for a family allowance if he has a dependent wife, but a woman only qualifies for a family allowance if her husband is disabled.<ref name="Pribble"/> Until a reform of paternity laws in 1998, children born outside marriage had less right to parental financial support and inheritance than children born within marriage.<ref name="haas"/> A bill was passed in 2007 to give mothers direct access to [[child support]] payments.<ref name="haas"/>
Working mothers of a certain low [[socioeconomic status]] and with proof of an employment contract and working hours receive subsidized [[child care]] through legislation passed in 1994. This system excludes: women whose household income is too high, unemployed women, women working in the informal sector, and women whose jobs are not by contract.<ref name="Pribble"/> Chile offers paid maternity leave for women working in the formal sector, paying women 100 percent of their salary during the leave, and also allows women a one-hour feeding break each day until the child has reached the age of two.<ref name="Pribble"/> Female workers unattached to the formal market and without an employment contract do not receive paid [[parental leave|maternity leave]].<ref name="Pribble"/>
Postnatal maternity leave is now six months instead of the previous three.<ref name=maternityleave>{{cite web|title=President Piñera enacts the law to extend postnatal maternity leave to 6 months|url=http://www.gob.cl/english/featured/2011/10/07/president-pinera-enacts-the-law-to-extend-postnatal-maternity-leave-to-6-months.htm|publisher=Gobierno de Chile|accessdate=7 April 2012|date=7 October 2011}}</ref>
==Education== [[File:Escolares-chilenos-Talcahuano.jpg|thumb|250px|School girls running in the school yard]] Women's [[literacy rates]] almost match those of men, with 97.4 percent of women being able to read, versus 97.6 percent of men (in 2015).<ref>https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/fields/2103.html</ref> Chilean law mandates compulsory primary and secondary education for children, boys and girls.<ref name="chile data"/> In 2007, the [[World Bank]] declared that enrollment levels for boys and girls in primary and secondary education were at a "virtual parity."<ref name=WB /> Women's education in Chile is generally higher than neighboring countries.<ref name=WB/> In higher education, as of 2002, women had similar attendance rates as men, with women at 47.5 percent attendance, versus men at 52.5 percent.<ref name="Punnett2006B">{{cite book|author=Betty Jane Punnett|title=Successful professional women of the Americas: from polar winds to tropical breezes|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kFJwEOd8Q70C&pg=PA214|accessdate=24 February 2012|year=2006|publisher=Edward Elgar Publishing|isbn=978-1-84542-437-4|page=212}}</ref>
==Employment==
===Participation=== Chile has one of the lowest rate of female employment in all of [[Latin America]], but women's workforce participation has steadily increased over the years.<ref name="un data">{{cite web|title=Chile|url=http://data.un.org/CountryProfile.aspx?crName=CHILE|publisher=United Nations|accessdate=18 March 2012|year=2012}}</ref> As of 2016, the [[employment rate]] of women was 52%.<ref name="stats.oecd.org">{{cite web|url=http://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DatasetCode=LFS_SEXAGE_I_R#|author=OECD|publisher=stats.oecd.org|title=LFS by sex and age - indicators|accessdate=13 March 2017}}</ref> Despite the fact that 47.5% of students in college are women, many still choose to be [[homemakers]] rather than join the workforce.<ref name="StangeOyster2011"/> A 2012 World Bank study showed that the expansion of public day care had no effect on female labor force participation.<ref name=WDR2012 /> The low number of women entering the labor force causes Chile to rank low amongst upper-middle class countries regarding women in the work force despite higher educational training.<ref name="WB"/> In Chile, poorer women make up a smaller share of the workforce.<ref name=WB/> A 2004 study showed that 81.4 percent of women worked in the [[tertiary sector of the economy|service sector]].<ref name="Punnett2006B"/>
===Formal and informal work=== Women have increasingly moved out of unpaid [[domestic worker|domestic work]] and into the paid formal and informal labor markets.<ref name="Pribble"/> Many female workers are in Chile's [[informal sector]] because national competition for jobs has increased the number of low-skill jobs.<ref name="Pribble"/> In 1998, 44.8 percent of working-aged women in Chile worked in the informal sector while only 32.9 percent of men worked informally.<ref name="Pribble"/>
===Income gap=== For jobs that do not require higher education, women make 20 percent less money on average than men. For jobs requiring a university degree, the gap in pay increases to 40 percent. Women without a university degree make 83 percent of the income men make without a university degree.<ref name="Punnett2006B"/> The quadrennial 2004 National Socio-Economic Survey and World Bank report in 2007 say that the overall gender income gap stands at 33 percent (since women make 67 percent of men's salaries).<ref name=WB />
==Politics==
===Female participation in politics=== Women were not involved in politics until 1934, when they could first use their municipal vote.<ref name=power>{{cite book|last=Power|first=Margaret|title=Right-wing women in Chile: feminine power and the struggle against Allende, 1964-1973|year=2002|publisher=Pennsylvania State University|location=University Park, PA|isbn=0-271-02174-8}}</ref> The municipal, and later national, vote caused women to involve themselves in politics more than before, pressuring the government and political parties.<ref name="dandavati"/> With women's increased political importance, many parties established women's sections for support and tried to pursue women's votes, though it would take years for political parties to truly view women as important to politics.<ref name="power"/> [[File:Feministas en lucha anti Pinochet (de Kena Lorenzini).jpg|thumb|250px|Chilean feminists gather in Santiago during Pinochet's regime]] [[File:Gladys Marín M.jpg|thumb|250px|[[Gladys Marín]] (1941–2005), Chilean activist and political figure. She was Secretary-General of the Communist Party of Chile (PCCh) (1994–2002) and then president of the PCCh until her death]] On December 1, 1971 thousands of women who were against the newly elected [[Salvador Allende]] marched through Santiago to protest government policies and [[Fidel Castro]]'s visiting of Chile.<ref name=power /> This march, known as the March of the Empty Pots and Pans, brought together many conservative and some liberal women as a force in Chilean politics,<ref name="power"/> and in 1977 Augusto Pinochet decreed the day of the march to be National Women's Day.<ref name=baldez>{{cite book|last=Baldez|first=Lisa|title=Why Women Protest|year=2002|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=United Kingdom|isbn=0-521-81150-3}}</ref> Women also made their voices heard in the late 1980s when 52 percent of the national electorate was female, and 51.2 percent of women voted "no" in Augusto Pinochet's [[referendum|plebiscite]].<ref name="dandavati"/> The women in these popular protests are considered to have played a central role in increasing national concern with the history of women's political activism.<ref name=klubock>{{cite journal|journal=Hispanic American Historical Review|year=2001|volume=81|author=Thomas Miller Klubock |title=Writing the History of Women and Gender in Twentieth-Century Chile|publisher=Duke University Press}}</ref>
As of 2006, Chile was lower than eight other Latin American countries in regards to women in political positions.<ref name=Econ1/> With only a few women legislators, sustaining attention to the topic of women's rights a difficult task, especially in the Senate, where there are fewer female representatives than in the [[Chamber of Deputies of Chile|Chamber of Deputies]].<ref name="haas"/> Unlike neighboring [[Argentina]], where 41.6 percent of the [[Argentine Chamber of Deputies]] is made up of women, only 15 percent of Chile's lower house is made up of female representatives.<ref name="Econ1"/> Chile has no government mandate requiring that women must make up a certain percentage of party candidates.<ref name="StangeOyster2011"/> Women's political representation is low but is on the rise in many political parties, and there is growing support for a quota law concerning women's representation.<ref name="haas"/> The progressive parties of the Left have greater openness to the participation of women, evident in the Party for Democracy's and Socialist Party's quotas for women's representation as candidates for internal party office.<ref name="haas"/>
In 2009, activists demanded that presidential candidates develop reforms that would improve work conditions for women. Reforms included [[maternity leave]], flexible work schedules and job training.<ref name="StangeOyster2011"/> Aimed at improving women's work opportunities, former president Michelle Bachelet made it illegal to ask for a job applicants' gender on applications and for employers to demand [[pregnancy tests]] be taken by employees in the public sector.<ref name=Econ1/>
===Second Wave Feminism=== Following these Chilean women, the contemporary phase of feminism was constructed through the social conflict between [[socialism]] and [[feminism]].<ref name="muse.jhu.edu">{{cite web|url=https://muse.jhu.edu/login?auth=0&type=summary&url=/journals/journal_of_womens_history/v015/15.3tobar.html|publisher=muse.jhu.edu|title=Project MUSE - "Feminism is Socialism, Liberty, and Much More:" Second-Wave Chilean Feminism and its Contentious Relationship with Socialism|accessdate=13 March 2017}}</ref> The democratically elected president, [[Salvador Allende|Allende]], was ousted on September 11, 1973 when a military coup invaded his palace, brutally excising all [[Popular Unity Government]] officials and resulting in Allende's debated suicide.<ref name="muse.jhu.edu"/> This revolution "The Chilean Road to Socialism" abruptly came to an end, revitalizing the foundation of the government. However, the foundation was hastily corrupted by patriarchal values. Prominent feminist sociologist [[Maria Elena Valenzuela]] argued, the military state can be interpreted as the quintessential expression of [[patriarchy]]: "The Junta, with a very clear sense of its interests, has understood that it must reinforce the traditional family, and the dependent role of women, which is reduced to that of mother.<ref name="muse.jhu.edu"/> The dictatorship, which institutionalizes [[social inequality]], is founded on inequality in the family." <ref name="muse.jhu.edu"/> These inequalities began to agitate Chilean women. Women began to formulate groups opposing the patriarchal domination of the political sphere.
===Michelle Bachelet's presidency=== [[Michelle Bachelet]] was the first female president of Chile, leading the country between 2006 and 2010.<ref name=WB /> During her presidency, Bachelet increased the budget of the [[National Women's Service]] (Servicio Nacional de la Mujer, SERNAM) and helped the institution gain funding from the United Nations Development Fund for Women.<ref name="haas"/> Her administration had an active role in furthering opportunities and policies for and about women, creating or improving [[child care]], [[pension]] reform and [[breastfeeding]] laws. During her presidency, Bachelet appointed a [[Cabinet of Chile|cabinet]] that was 50 percent female.<ref name="haas"/>
Bachelet served as the first executive director of [[UN Women|United Nations Entity for Gender Equality and the Empowerment of Women]].<ref name="haas"/>
On March 11, 2014, she became president of Chile for the second time.
===Policy=== The [[National Women's Service]] (SERNAM) has noticed that it is easier to get politicians to support and pass poverty-alleviation programs aimed at poor women than proposals that challenge gender relations.<ref name="haas"/> Much of Chile's legislation concerning women's rights has been pushed by SERNAM: Between 1992 and 2010, sixty-four legislative proposals to expand women's legal equality were introduced by SERNAM.<ref name="haas"/>
Historically the progressive parties of the Left have drawn more attention to women's rights.<ref name="haas"/> Yet many political parties insincerely support women's agenda and the concept of gender equality, instead leaving any action to be taken by SERNAM or nongovernmental organizations.<ref name="dandavati"/>
Although SERNAM exists to aid women, there is no non-discrimination clause in the [[Constitution of Chile|Political Constitution of the Republic of Chile]].<ref name="chile data"/>
==Organizations==
===State=== The [[National Women's Service]] is the political institution created in 1991 that crafts executive bills concerning women's rights.<ref name="haas"/> Its Spanish name is Servicio Nacional de la Mujer, or SERNAM; it has established a program to aid female heads of households, a program for prevention of violence against women, and a network of information centers that focus on the issues of women's rights.<ref name="haas"/> Its presence in Chile is important because it was established by law and is a permanent part of Chile's state structure.<ref name="Impact SERNAM">{{cite journal|title="State Feminism" and Women's Movements: The Impact of Chile's Servicio Nacinoal de la Mujer on Women's Activism|journal=Latin American Research Review|date=February 2003|volume=38|issue=1|author=Susan Franceschet|publisher=University of Texas Press|location=Austin, TX}}</ref> As an institution it tends to focus much of its attention on certain segments of women: low-income women heads of households, women seasonal workers, domestic violence prevention, and teen pregnancy prevention.<ref name="Impact SERNAM"/>
A common complaint that SERNAM has is that the top appointees are not women linked to the feminist community.<ref name="haas"/> The institution also has restrictions when it comes to policy regarding women due to its state ties, as seen in 2000 when SERNAM favored but would not explicitly support the bill to legalize divorce because it was under the leadership of the Christian Democratic party. In 2002 it was finally allowed to support the bill.<ref name="haas"/>
===Research and activism=== Many of Chile's women's groups function outside the state sphere.<ref name="Pribble"/>
Centers for research began to emerge in the later part of the twentieth century, including the Centro de Estudios de la Mujer (The Women's Study Center) and La Morada.<ref name="klubock"/> The Women's Study Center is a [[nonprofit organization]] founded in 1984 and conducts research, trains women, has a consulting program, and tries to increase women's political participation.<ref name=CEM>{{cite web|title=About CEM|url=http://www.cem.cl/eque.htm}}</ref> La Morada is another nonprofit organization that works to expand the rights of women through political involvement, education, culture, and efforts to eradicate violence.<ref name="la morada">{{cite web|title=La Morada|url=http://www.lamorada.cl/}}</ref>
===International relations=== Chile ratified the United Nation's [[Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women]] in 1988, internationally declaring support for women's [[human rights]].<ref name=baldez />
One of Chile's missions as part of the UN is commitment to democracy, human rights and gender perspective as foundations of multilateral action.<ref name="chile government UN page">{{cite web|title=Objcetives and Functions|url=http://chileabroad.gov.cl/onu/en/sobre-la-mision/objetivos-y-funciones/|publisher=Government of Chile|accessdate=14 April 2012|author=Permanent Mission of Chile to the UN}}</ref>
==Crimes against women==
=== Domestic violence === {{Main|Domestic violence in Chile}}
[[Domestic violence]] in Chile is a serious issue affecting a large percentage of the population, especially among lower income demographics.<ref name="report">[https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2006/78884.htm Report on Human Rights Practices 2006: Chile]. [[United States]] [[Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor]] (March 6, 2007). ''This article incorporates text from this source, which is in the [[public domain]].''</ref> The Intrafamily Violence Law passed in 1994 was the first political measure to address violence in the home, but because the law would not pass without being accepted by both sides, the law was weak in the way it addressed victim protection and punishment for abusers.<ref name="haas"/> The law was later reformed in 2005.<ref>http://www.cepal.org/oig/doc/Chi200520066ModificaLeyVIF1994.pdf</ref> A 2004 [[National Women's Service|SERNAM]] study reported that 50 percent of married women in Chile had suffered spousal abuse, 34 percent reported having suffered physical violence, and 16 percent reported psychological abuse.<ref name="report"/> According to another study from 2004, 90 percent of low-income women in Chile experience some type of domestic violence.<ref name="Cianelli2004">{{cite journal|last=Cianelli|first=R.|author2=Ferrer, L. |author3=Peragallo, N. |title=Low income Chilean women confronting HIV/AIDS and domestic violence|journal=The XV International AIDS Conference|year=2004|url=http://www.iasociety.org/Default.aspx?pageId=11&abstractId=2169470|accessdate=24 February 2012|location=Bangkok, Thailand}}</ref> Due to the high prevalence of domestic violence, many Chilean women accept it as normal.<ref name="Cianelli2004"/> The legalization of divorce in 2004 won the approval of women throughout the country, especially those concerned about [[domestic violence]], as women were previously unable to escape abusive relationships due to the divorce laws.<ref name="StangeOyster2011"/>
From January to November 2005, 76,000 cases of family violence were reported to the ''[[Carabineros de Chile|Carabineros]]''; 67,913 were reported by women, 6,404 by men, and approximately 1,000 by children.<ref name="report"/>
=== Rape === [[Rape]], including [[spousal rape]], is a criminal offense. Penalties for rape range from five to 15 years' imprisonment, and the government generally enforces the law.<ref name="report"/> In 2004 the Criminal Code was changed so that the age for statutory rape is 14; previously, the age was 12.<ref name=Ahumada>{{cite journal|last=Ahumada|first=Claudia|title=Statutory Rape Law in Chile: For or Against Adolescents?|journal=Journal of Politics and Law|date=June 2009|volume=2|issue=2|url=http://www.ccsenet.org/journal/index.php/jpl/article/view/2311/2168|accessdate=11 April 2012}}</ref> The law protects the privacy and safety of the person making the charge. In 2006 from January to November, police received reports of 1,926 cases of rape, compared with 2,451 cases in all of 2005; experts believed that most rape cases go unreported. The Ministry of Justice and the PICH have several offices specifically to provide counseling and assistance in rape cases.<ref name=report/> A number of NGOs, such as La Morada Corporation for Women, provide counseling for rape victims.<ref name=klubock />
=== Sexual harassment === A 2005 law against [[sexual harassment]] provides protection and financial compensation to victims and penalizes harassment by employers or co-workers.<ref name="report"/> The law provides [[severance package|severance pay]] to anyone who resigns due to being a victim of sexual harassment if she/he has worked for the employer for at least one year.<ref name=report2010>{{cite web|title=2010 Human Rights Report: Chile|url=https://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2010/wha/154498.htm|publisher=U.S. Department of State|accessdate=13 April 2012|author=Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor|date=8 April 2011}}</ref> During 2005 the Labor Directorate received 244 complaints of sexual harassment,<ref name="report"/> and in 2009 there were 82 complaints were received.<ref name="report2010"/> The majority of the complaints come from women.<ref name=becerra>{{cite web|last=Becerra|first=Lidia Casas|title=An Exploratory Study of Sexual Harassment Complaints in Chile|url=http://www.ialsnet.org/meetings/labour/papers/Casas-Chile.pdf|publisher=International Association of Law Schools: Diego Portales University Law School|accessdate=13 April 2012|year=2006}}</ref>
=== Discrimination === A 2005 study by ''Corporacion Humana'' and the [[University of Chile]]'s Institute of Public Affairs revealed that 87 percent of women surveyed felt that women suffered discrimination. According to the survey, 95 percent believed women faced discrimination in the labor market, 67 percent believed they faced discrimination in politics, 61 percent felt that women were discriminated against by the media, and 54 percent within the family.<ref name=report/>
==Other concerns==
===Family=== Today, younger women are opting out of marriage and having fewer children than their predecessors.<ref name="StangeOyster2011"/> The total fertility rate as of 2015 was 1.82 children born/woman.<ref name="cia">{{cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/ci.html|publisher=cia.gov|title=The World Factbook — Central Intelligence Agency|accessdate=13 March 2017}}</ref> This is below the replacement rate of 2.1, and also lower than in previous years. A 2002 study reported that urban women averaged 2.1 children per woman, with women living in rural areas having more children, at 2.9. As of the 1990s, both urban and rural women were averaging fewer children than previously. For those women who do have children, after former president Michelle Bachelet's childcare mandates, childcare centers that provide free services are four times more numerous. Nursing mothers also have the legal right to breastfeed during the workday.<ref name="StangeOyster2011"/> Women are less likely to seek divorces and marriage annulments.<ref name="Punnett2006D"/>
===Health and sexuality=== Women in Chile have long [[life expectancy]], living an average of 80.8 years, about six years longer than men.<ref name="StangeOyster2011">{{cite book|author1=Mary Zeiss Stange|author2=Carol K. Oyster|author3=Jane E. Sloan|title=Encyclopedia of Women in Today's World|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bOkPjFQoBj8C&pg=PA280|accessdate=24 February 2012|date=23 February 2011|publisher=SAGE|isbn=978-1-4129-7685-5|pages=280–}}</ref><ref name="Punnett2006D">{{cite book|author=Betty Jane Punnett|title=Successful professional women of the Americas: from polar winds to tropical breezes|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kFJwEOd8Q70C&pg=PA214|accessdate=24 February 2012|year=2006|publisher=Edward Elgar Publishing|isbn=978-1-84542-437-4|page=214}}</ref> [[Sex education]] is rarely taught in schools and is considered "taboo" by many Chilean families. Friends and family usually are the main source of sex education.<ref name=HIV1/> In 1994, Chile decriminalized [[adultery]].<ref>''Women and Democracy: Latin America and Central and Eastern Europe'', edited by Jane S. Jaquette, Sharon L. Wolchik, page 62</ref>
====HIV/AIDS==== The [[HIV/AIDS]] rate in Chile was estimated in 2012 at 0.4% of adults aged 15–49.<ref name="cia2">{{cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/rankorder/2155rank.html|publisher=cia.gov|title=The World Factbook — Central Intelligence Agency|accessdate=13 March 2017}}</ref> While cases of [[HIV]] and [[AIDS]] in women have stabilized internationally, Chile has seen a rise in HIV/AIDS infection. Societal beliefs about traditional women's roles as mothers leads to women being less likely to use contraceptives, increasing the opportunity for disease. Chilean women also often feel subordinate to men due to these traditional belief systems, making women less likely to negotiate for the use of [[condoms]]. In 2007, 28 percent of people with HIV/AIDS in Chile were women. Numbers of women living with HIV is lower than those with AIDS. A study by Vivo Positivo showed that 85 percent of women living with HIV/AIDS reported that they had little to no education or information about HIV/AIDS until diagnosis.<ref name=HIV1/>
A 2004 study found that Chilean women with HIV/AIDS were susceptible to coerced [[Sterilisation (medicine)|sterilization]]. Fifty-six percent of HIV-positive Chilean women reported being pressured by health-care workers to prevent pregnancy by being sterilized. Of the women who chose to be sterilized, half were forced or persuaded to do so. Women victims of [[domestic abuse]] face a higher risk of getting HIV, and in 2004, 56 percent of women who have HIV and 77 percent of women with HIV/AIDS were victims of domestic abuse, sexual abuse, or rape before their diagnosis.<ref name=HIV1>{{cite web|last=|first=|title=Dignity Denied: Violations of the Rights of HIV-Positive Women in Chilean Health Facilities |url=http://reproductiverights.org/sites/crr.civicactions.net/files/documents/chilereport_FINAL_singlepages.pdf |work=[[Center for Reproductive Rights]]|accessdate=24 February 2012|date=}}</ref>
====Abortion==== {{See|Abortion in Chile}} Between 1989 and 2017, Chile had some of the strictest [[abortion]] laws in the world, banning the procedure completely.<ref>[https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-41005517 "Chile abortion: Court approves easing total ban"] at BBC News.</ref> The current law allows abortion if the mother's life in danger, in case of lethal malformations of the fetus, or in cases of rape.<ref>http://www.diariooficial.interior.gob.cl/publicaciones/2017/09/23/41866/01/1276248.pdf</ref>
==Notable Chilean women== [[File:Gabriela Mistral-01.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Gabriela Mistral]], the first Latin American woman to win a [[Nobel Prize for Literature]].]] [[File:Cantinera Irene Morales(1865-1890).jpg|thumb|upright|[[Irene Morales (soldier)|Irene Morales]], a soldier during the War of the Pacific who was recognized for her valor.]] ;Literature Chile has a rich literary history, being described as the "Land of the Poets." *In 1945, [[Gabriela Mistral]] was the first Latin American, including men and women, to win the [[Nobel Prize for Literature]].<ref name="mujeres que hacen historia" /><ref name="Punnett2006A">{{cite book|author=Betty Jane Punnett|title=Successful professional women of the Americas: from polar winds to tropical breezes|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kFJwEOd8Q70C&pg=PA214|accessdate=24 February 2012|year=2006|publisher=Edward Elgar Publishing|isbn=978-1-84542-437-4|page=210}}</ref> *Other notable female authors from Chile include [[Isabel Allende]], [[Marta Brunet]], [[María Luisa Bombal]], [[Marcela Paz]], and [[Mercedes Valdivieso]].
;Politics {{update|section|date=October 2017}} *In 1999, [[Gladys Marín]] was one of the first women to be a presidential candidate in Chile.<ref name="mujeres que hacen historia" /> The year before, she was the first person in Chile to charge [[Augusto Pinochet]] for crimes committed during his dictatorship.<ref name="mujeres que hacen historia" /> *[[Sara Larraín]] was the other woman, along with Marín, to be one of the first female presidential candidates in Chile.<ref name="mujeres que hacen historia" /> *From 2006 until 2010, [[Michelle Bachelet]] served as the first woman president of Chile.<ref name="StangeOyster2011"/> *In the 2006 election, [[Soledad Alvear]], a [[Christian Democrat]], ran for the presidency against Bachelet.<ref name="Punnett2006C">{{cite book|author=Betty Jane Punnett|title=Successful professional women of the Americas: from polar winds to tropical breezes|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kFJwEOd8Q70C&pg=PA214|accessdate=24 February 2012|year=2006|publisher=Edward Elgar Publishing|isbn=978-1-84542-437-4|page=213}}</ref> She is also the woman responsible for organizing and structuring [[National Women's Service|SERNAM]].<ref name="mujeres que hacen historia" /> *The daughter of late President [[Salvador Allende]], [[Isabel Allende (politician)|Isabel Allende]], also second cousin to the author of the same name, is a prominent Chilean politician. *Senator [[Carolina Tohá]] is the president of the [[Party for Democracy (Chile)|Party for Democracy]]. *[[Camila Vallejo]] has risen in national and international popularity as a leader of the [[2011–2012 Chilean protests|Chilean student movement]] as well as a member of the Central Committee of [[Communist Youth of Chile]].
;Other *Chile's first canonized saint of the [[Roman Catholic Church]] is [[Teresa de los Andes]], a [[Discalced Carmelites|Discalced Carmelite]], canonized by [[Pope John Paul II]] in 1993. *[[Javiera Carrera|Javiera Carrera Verdugo]] was the first woman to have sewn a national flag of Chile.<ref name="mujeres que hacen historia" /> *[[Candelaria Pérez]] and [[Irene Morales (soldier)|Irene Morales]] were [[cantinière]]s who fought in the [[War of the Confederation]] and [[War of the Pacific]], respectively, and were recognized for their courage in battle.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.biografiadechile.cl/detalle.php?IdContenido=218&IdCategoria=8&IdArea=31&TituloPagina=Historia+de+Chile|title= Irene Morales Infante: 1865–1890. Mujer destacada en la Guerra del Pacífica|publisher= Biografía de Chile |first= Cristián|last= Guerrero Lira|first2=Fernando |last2=Ramírez Morales|first3=Isabel |last3=Torres Dujisin |language=Spanish|accessdate=10 September 2014}}</ref> *Margot Duhalde was the first female war pilot from Chile, having flown for the [[Air Transport Auxiliary]] of the [[Royal Air Force]] in [[World War II]].<ref name="mujeres que hacen historia" /><ref>[[:es:Margot Duhalde]]</ref>
